headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Christie, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Cablevision Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Cindi Buckwalter, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning and welcome to Cablevision's Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO of Cablevision; Gregg Seibert, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer; Brian Sweeney, President and incoming C
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning and welcome to Cablevision's Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO of Cablevision; Gregg Seibert, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer; Brian Sweeney, President and incoming Chief Financial Officer; and Kristin Dolan, Chief Operating Officer. Following a discussion of the company's fourth quarter 2014 results, we will open the call for questions. If you do not have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com. 
Please note the following. Today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call. On Page 7 of today's earnings release, we provide a reconciliation of operating income to adjusted operating cash flow, or AOCF. 
I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindi, and good morning. Cablevision delivered strong financial results in 2014, while continuing to transform the Optimum experience. We developed higher-quality customer relationships by offering products and services that provide superior va
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindi, and good morning. Cablevision delivered strong financial results in 2014, while continuing to transform the Optimum experience. We developed higher-quality customer relationships by offering products and services that provide superior value, provided expanded connectivity inside and outside the home, and enhancing the performance of our network. Our full year 2014 financial results reflect our progress. 
Total company net revenue increased nearly 4% and AOCF increased by 9% compared with 2013. Our capital expenditures were $892 million, 6% lower than 2013. Full year 2014 free cash flow was $487 million, and we declared a $0.15 per share quarterly dividend on February 24. Our fourth quarter net customer results compared favorably with the third quarter. We added data customers, despite significant competitive discounting and economic pressures in portions of our footprint. We also significantly reduced the loss of our customer relationships, even in our most competitive areas. Our results reflect a decrease in move and nonpay related churn versus the third quarter. 
During the fourth quarter, we continue to deliver strong year-over-year growth in revenue per customer. Disciplined approaches to pricing, promotional eligibility and customer credit policies are key elements of our strategy. While these policies reduced the number of our available sales opportunities, we believe they contribute to a stronger base of customers over time. We plan to continue these policies in 2015, while differentiating the value of Optimum in the marketplace. 
During 2014, we introduced several new products and enhancements. Let me mention some of them of the more notable initiatives. We introduced 2 new Optimum Online speed tiers, we enhanced our TV to GO video experience by integrating more than 50 networks into the Optimum app, we improved our Multi-Room DVR by increasing simultaneous recording to 15 shows, we also signed our first advertising clients to our new data and analytics service. In addition to these product enhancements, we continue to improve our customer service activity. 2014 total customer service phone calls declined by nearly 16%.
Trouble cost truck rolls declined 21% each as compared with 2013. These achievements reflect the contributions of our nearly 15,000 employees. In 2014, we continue to invest in our people in the transform our culture to one that is more performance base. We did this through new recognition, training and development programs, as well as a new nonexecutive performance bonus plan. 
And finally, let's discuss our WiFi initiatives.
In 2014, we launched our newest WiFi smart router. We also surpassed our goal of reaching more than 1 million Optimum WiFi access points within our service area. We continue to see remarkable growth in Optimum WiFi usage. During the fourth quarter, our customers used more than 4x the amount of data than during the fourth quarter of 2013. 
WiFi is a critical part of our product strategy and one of our most important strategic assets. As I've noted before, we plan to continue to innovate in this area, which brings me to Freewheel, our most recent effort to monetize our investment in WiFi. Freewheel is the first all WiFi device from a cable provider. It is available nationwide and delivers unlimited data talk and text. It works anywhere in the world where you are connected to WiFi. Freewheel is backed by our carrier-grade Optimum WiFi network with 1.1 million hotspots in the tri-state area. 
Today, Optimum WiFi customers pass an average of more than 6 gigabytes of data per month, that is really 3x more data than the most commonly purchased data plans from cellular providers. Against this backdrop, we believe Freewheel will be the beginning of a disruptive force to the cellular industry. 
As a company, we are solidifying our position as our customers prefer connectivity company. Freewheel is a natural progression of this strategy. This the first in a series of new products and services, which we intend to launch in order to better serve our customers. 
For 3 years, we have been improving our relationships with our customers. Today, service quality has become a key differentiator of the Optimum experience, and we remain committed to being the best service provider in the industry. In 2015, as we continue this important work, we expect to introduce additional innovative products and repackage certain of our current offerings. Our goal is to meet and exceed the rapidly evolving demands of our customers. 
With that, we'll now turn the call over to Gregg Seibert.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim, and good morning. Total company fourth quarter net revenue increased 3% and AOCF declined by 3.4%, as compared with the prior year period. Capital expenditures were $262 million compared with $211 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. Fou
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim, and good morning. Total company fourth quarter net revenue increased 3% and AOCF declined by 3.4%, as compared with the prior year period. Capital expenditures were $262 million compared with $211 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. Fourth quarter free cash flow was $88 million. 
During the quarter, we gained nearly 4,000 net high-speed data customers. Customer relationships and voice customers both decreased by 11,000 and video customers declined by 34,000. 
Fourth quarter average monthly revenue per customer increased by nearly $8 to $155.20 as compared with the prior year period. This increase is consistent with our pricing strategies and principally reflects recent rate initiatives, our disciplined approach to promotional eligibility and higher advertising revenue.
Fourth quarter total cable revenue increased by 3.1%, reflecting the increase in revenue per customer, which was partially offset by fewer customer relationships. 
As compared with 2013, fourth quarter cable advertising revenue increased by 9%, driven primarily by increased political and issue-related spending. This growth was offset in part by lower banking and leisure spending. Our audience data and addressable advertising campaigns contributed to this growth, and we are successfully attracting new national advertisers our advanced advertising and capabilities. 
Cable AOCF declined 4.6% in the fourth quarter, as compared with the prior year period. This primarily reflects the impact of fewer customers and higher programming, employee-related and marketing costs, as well as higher legal expenses and other fees. This was partially offset by revenue growth and lower cost associated with the decline in trouble call related truck rolls and customer service calls. 
Cable's fourth quarter AOCF margin was 30.3%. Full year 2014 AOCF margin was 31.7%, slightly higher than the prior year period comparable margin of 31.2%. Cable capital spending in the fourth quarter was $222 million, a $46 million increase from the same period in 2013. This increase reflects the timing of CPE purchases and higher spending on WiFi and support capital. 
Total cable capital spending for 2014 was approximately 8% lower than the comparable 2013 level. AOCF and capital expenditures for the fourth quarter reflect modest prelaunch investments in Freewheel. 
Lifepath fourth quarter revenue increased 6.2% and AOCF increased 10% over the prior year period. These increases reflect revenue growth in Ethernet-based services, partially offset by the continuing decline in legacy TDM-based services. 
During 2014, Lightpath network expanded to approximately 7,400 buildings, an increase of 600 connections. Lightpath also 100 gigabit optical transport services and managed videoconferencing to its suite of products. Lightpath's expanding product portfolio and nearly ubiquitous footprint continue to present us with a great opportunity to grow into the mid- and large enterprises base. 
In our other segment, fourth quarter revenue was essentially flat and the AOCF deficit improved by 4.5%. These results principally reflect higher advertising revenue at News 12, partially offset by lower advertising revenue at Newsday. AOCF also reflects reduced expenditures of certain other businesses.
We continue to focus on transforming the Optimum experience and strengthening our position as the market's premier connectivity company by investing in our network, products and employees, while continuing to respond to the evolving marketplace with innovative products, such as Freewheel. 
Looking forward to 2015, we currently anticipate that total company AOCF and CapEx, including incremental expenditures for Freewheel, will be substantially similar to our 2014 results. However, this is a dynamic business, and we anticipate updating our guidance as the year progresses. 
Now turning to the company's financial position. The company's fourth quarter consolidated cash position was $850 million and net debt was $7.9 billion. We had a -- we had $1.43 billion undrawn and available under the $1.5 billion revolving credit facility at CSC Holdings as of the end of 2014. 
During 2014, we executed a number of successful financing transactions, which extended our maturities, strengthened our balance sheet and improved our strong liquidity position, while funding our quarterly dividend. We plan to apply our 2015 free cash flow in a similar manner.
In May, we issued $750 million of 5.25% senior notes due 2024 at par, which was the lowest the bond issuance coupon in the company's history. The net proceeds and a portion of our cash on hand were used to repay $750 million of our Term Loan B credit facility. 
Later in the year, CSC Holdings made a $200 million voluntary repayment of its Term Loan B facility. This transaction results in cash interest savings over the remaining term of the facility, as well as improving our debt maturity profile by reducing our 2020 debt maturities. We also use of cash on hand to opportunistically repurchase approximately $37 million of Cablevision's senior notes. This was executed at an average price below par and will generate cash interest savings over the term of the notes. 
At December 31, the company's consolidated net leverage ratio was 4.5x. The CSC Holdings Restricted Group bank leverage ratio was 3.1x. 
In calculating our total company leverage ratio, AOCF is determined using latest quarter annualized AOCF. As a result, our leverage ratios are more sensitive to changes in quarterly AOCF than they would be if our leverage was measured based on trailing 12 month AOCF. 
We did not repurchase shares of Cablevision stock during 2014. We have approximately $450 million of remaining stock repurchase authorization. 
Finally, in June, Charter Communications reached a settlement with the Montana Department of Revenue related to a property tax dispute that was originally litigated during our ownership of communications. As a result, during the fourth quarter, we received substantially all of the approximately $6.6 million in cash that we expect to receive from Charter as a result of this settlement. 
Operator, we're now prepared to open the call for questions.

componenttextpreview: Two questions. First, Gregg, can you just clarify when you talk about AOCF and CapEx being similar in 2015 and 2014, are you talking about an absolute basis or growth?
componenttext: Two questions. First, Gregg, can you just clarify when you talk about AOCF and CapEx being similar in 2015 and 2014, are you talking about an absolute basis or growth?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm talking about absolute numbers, Marci. And I think the -- as we look to the 2015 guidance, as everybody on this call is aware, we manage this business on a long-term basis. We're not managing it for quarterly earnings. And one of the things that
componenttext: Well, I'm talking about absolute numbers, Marci. And I think the -- as we look to the 2015 guidance, as everybody on this call is aware, we manage this business on a long-term basis. We're not managing it for quarterly earnings. And one of the things that's very important to us is to be able to manage the business in a dynamic fashion. Jim alluded to the fact that we're considering additional new products this year. And while we have nothing to announce today, we're trying to do is provide guidance [indiscernible] thoughtful guidance. We were -- last year, we had a tiny bit of criticism for the fact that we were conservative in our guidance. I'm not saying that we're conservative in the guidance for 2015 but again, rather thoughtful. As we look at AOCF percentage changes, the 1 percentage point change in AOCF is roughly $18 million. That's a relatively small amount when you're talking about the numbers, the magnitude that this business generates. So from our perspective, we're optimistic about 2015, but we are going to update the guidance as we go through the year, and we're comfortable looking at AOCF and capital being substantially similar to where they came in, in 2014.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

componenttext: And then my follow-up is for Jim, you mentioned in your opening comments, the competitive environment, which I think you probably mentioned every quarter. Is there anything that you're seeing that's different now either in the fourth quarter going into the first quarter?

componenttextpreview: Gregg, just if you could think more on the CapEx side. You said pretty elevated CPA with some of the project work you've been undertaking and not to sort of shed light on what '15 projects look like, but I guess, sort of looking and saying why shouldn't b
componenttext: Gregg, just if you could think more on the CapEx side. You said pretty elevated CPA with some of the project work you've been undertaking and not to sort of shed light on what '15 projects look like, but I guess, sort of looking and saying why shouldn't be that a lower number in '15? And then if you could, maybe just a comment on cash taxes for 2015?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let's start with the cash tax comment. Thankfully, we have bonus depreciation again. So I do not anticipate that we'll run through the NOL in 2015. So cash taxes will be quite light yet again. In terms of the capital side of the equation, Mike, you
componenttext: Sure. Let's start with the cash tax comment. Thankfully, we have bonus depreciation again. So I do not anticipate that we'll run through the NOL in 2015. So cash taxes will be quite light yet again. In terms of the capital side of the equation, Mike, you call out the CPU number, and we had an increase in CPE in the fourth quarter, but a lot of what happens with CBE, as you know, is timing of expenditures, and we ended up with additional purchases of boxes, of managed routers, some remotes in the fourth quarter, but it's not necessarily CPE that will keep capital expenditures sort of roughly these levels. We continue to invest in WiFi. We continue to across the board invest in our network, and we're going to continue those efforts. As you'll recall from a few years ago, there was a period where we didn't feel the plant was up to the capability it needed to be up to, that's not going as we said many times, that's not going to happen again. We're going to keep the level of investment off to a point where we can truly realize this ambition of being the premier connectivity company in the New York marketplace.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, actually do is talk just a tiny bit about the gross margin items in the quarter, because we had a couple of items that jumped off the sheet, which you'll see in -- you'll see in the K because, for example, our cable recurring revenue was up $40 mill
componenttext: Well, actually do is talk just a tiny bit about the gross margin items in the quarter, because we had a couple of items that jumped off the sheet, which you'll see in -- you'll see in the K because, for example, our cable recurring revenue was up $40 million in the quarter, our programming costs were up $25 million. So you would normally expect to more of the margin improvement under that type of scenario, but we had $10 million of severance in the quarter. Severance in the fourth quarter of 2013 was below the AOCF line item because of the fact that we had a formal restructuring. This year, it's not, so that's a $10 million delta. And advertising expense was up by $13 million year-over-year. Some of that was related to the Freewheel launch and those 2 items and some additional fees associated with the launch of Freewheel and impact on the quarter. So those were sort of the bigger items. There was some increase in compensation costs, but that's something that happens fairly frequently in the fourth quarter as we true-up the ultimate incentive programs to the actual results for the year.

componenttext: I have 3, if that's okay. The first is for Jim, Gregg, and Kristin. Jim you said at the beginning of the call that WiFi is one of your most important strategic assets. Obviously, you're starting with Freewheel, can you give us your longer-term like how you're thinking about things over the longer term?

componenttext: You mean about WiFi or just overall about the company?

componenttext: Well, if you want to do both, that's fine. I meant WiFi because you said important strategical assets?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, sure. And the -- I mean, WiFi is connectivity, and connectivity on a wireless basis. And what we're seeing in the marketplace and what we believe is the, for a lack of a better term, the wave of the future is more and more and more reliance on WiFi
componenttext: Okay, sure. And the -- I mean, WiFi is connectivity, and connectivity on a wireless basis. And what we're seeing in the marketplace and what we believe is the, for a lack of a better term, the wave of the future is more and more and more reliance on WiFi by our customers because they -- their use of data is going, but also, for instance, if you went to the Consumer Electronics Show this year, they -- I don't think there was hardly anything on the floor that wasn't connected using a WiFi device. I didn't see one thing, by the way, being connected by the way by a cellular device. The -- what all of this tells us that connectivity, particularly on a wireless this is going to become more and more important to our consumer. We want to be the company that provides that connectivity. We want to be the company that's seen as being the best at providing that connectivity. Now, we think that that's sort of the first part of the wave. The second part is that there are products and services that will go along with that strategic position. The first of which you've just seen, which is Freewheel. But there will be others. And we feel that we will be poised and ready to take advantage of the strategic position that we've created by investing in WiFi in order to do that. Other than that, from the company point of view, I would say that the other thing that we see, which is really very closely related is that connectivity has surpassed video as the primary product for a company like ours. And we need to continue to strategize our product offerings to reflect with different packaging, et cetera, which is something I think we will do in 2015.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And with one for Gregg. Just one more specific, but you mentioned that there was an increase in the buildout, I think, you said 600 buildings. Is there a way that you could good size how big opportunity as you continue to increase buildings, is the
componenttext: Great. And with one for Gregg. Just one more specific, but you mentioned that there was an increase in the buildout, I think, you said 600 buildings. Is there a way that you could good size how big opportunity as you continue to increase buildings, is there, like a potential market size that you can address?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the Lightpath side, Jessica, the building talent matters a lot, but it matters in 2 directions. One of the way -- when I first started working closely with David who runs Lightpath a couple of years ago, one of the key attributes of the business at tha
componenttext: On the Lightpath side, Jessica, the building talent matters a lot, but it matters in 2 directions. One of the way -- when I first started working closely with David who runs Lightpath a couple of years ago, one of the key attributes of the business at that point in time we were spending roughly $0.35 in capital for every dollar of revenue that we were generating. And I think that we had very high AOCF margin in that business, which was a great, but when you're putting so much back into capital, the free cash flow profile of the business is not as attractive as the free cash flow profile is in cable. And one of the things that we were doing was we were lighting a lot of additional buildings and not getting the same type of sell-through or at least, sort of targeted type of sell-through for additional tenants in already wired buildings. So I think, what Dave and his team are doing now is they're selectively lighting new buildings when they have a new anchor tenant, but one of the reasons the margins has been expanding, particularly the cash flow margin in that business has been the fact that we are doing a better job of making sure that we're marketing through secondary tenants in those buildings. We don't have to light a new building in the Lightpath business in order to generate incremental revenue. The cash flow characteristics of that account becomes substantially better. I'd argue lots of growth opportunity for Lightpath people imagine some of the new managed services they're providing and lots of room in the footprint. It's still a very fragmented business of which we have a minority share and my expectations is that we're going to keep building that share.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

componenttextpreview: I don't think I can speak directly to Nielsen. What I will say is that the value of census level, which is household data down to individual homes versus an extrapolation that we always talk about the fact that Nielsen has 365 people meters in the entire
componenttext: I don't think I can speak directly to Nielsen. What I will say is that the value of census level, which is household data down to individual homes versus an extrapolation that we always talk about the fact that Nielsen has 365 people meters in the entire New York footprint, which the amount of sales that we offer shows a big difference of us being able to monitor every single channel tuned in real time for every single setup across our entire footprint. So if you look at the 365 boxes to indicate activity versus 7 million desktops, I think you kind of get a sense of why the advertisers are interested and why it matters.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions. You spent a lot of time talking about WiFi. Do you expect that you could actually increase your market share outside of the current footprint? My second question is more for Gregg. As you look into 2015, you gave a lot of AOCF and free cash
componenttext: Two questions. You spent a lot of time talking about WiFi. Do you expect that you could actually increase your market share outside of the current footprint? My second question is more for Gregg. As you look into 2015, you gave a lot of AOCF and free cash flow guidance, at what point could you actually tap down on the buyback?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take the buyback question first, which is at this point in time, we continue to have our $0.15 per share quarterly dividend. That's a very attractive return-of-capital for our shareholders. And at this point, we're looking at that really as the
componenttext: Well, I'll take the buyback question first, which is at this point in time, we continue to have our $0.15 per share quarterly dividend. That's a very attractive return-of-capital for our shareholders. And at this point, we're looking at that really as the primary return of capital. The additional free cash flow that we generated above and beyond the dividend [indiscernible] last year was for the most part, used for debt reduction. And I think that we're going to continue to be prudent in the way that we run our leverage and maturity profiles. So I think that to the extent we're generating free cash flow in excess of the dividend, it is much more likely that you will see us use that free cash flow to pay down additional debt rather than to repurchase shares at this point. But again, if there was a market event, if there was -- we'll continue to be opportunistic and that's one of the reasons we keep the share repurchase program in place.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: As far as going outside of our footprint, the -- I assume you're talking about Freewheel because as far as the network and enable systems go, we best we certainly have no plans to go out and overbuild anybody, because we don't think they were. But the Fre
componenttext: As far as going outside of our footprint, the -- I assume you're talking about Freewheel because as far as the network and enable systems go, we best we certainly have no plans to go out and overbuild anybody, because we don't think they were. But the Freewheel is available across the United States and actually, across the world and we are seeing uses for the product outside of our footprint. In fact, Kristin, you want to talk about Europe or...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're seeing some interest, really enthusiastic interest from expats and from people who travel frequently outside the country because they're able to maintain the U.S. phone number, they don't incur any roaming charges when they're on WiFi either
componenttext: Yes, so we're seeing some interest, really enthusiastic interest from expats and from people who travel frequently outside the country because they're able to maintain the U.S. phone number, they don't incur any roaming charges when they're on WiFi either in particularly where there's a lot of WiFi available and throughout Europe. So the idea of having a flat rate U.S. sort of that phone that they can use to conduct all their U.S. business is one of the sort of interesting opportunities for us that we've uncovered as we started rolling out Freewheel. So we think there's more opportunity there, particularly in Europe and also in the Caribbean.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you guys had about $935 million of federal gross NOLs at the end of '13. I was wondering if you could update us on where those are at year-end '14? And when do you expect to become a full cash taxpayer, what year? And Is it important for you to ei
componenttext: I think you guys had about $935 million of federal gross NOLs at the end of '13. I was wondering if you could update us on where those are at year-end '14? And when do you expect to become a full cash taxpayer, what year? And Is it important for you to either minimize or not pay sizable federal income taxes in the long-term?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Jason. So right now, the balance of the NOL is at $620 million. I would have predicted at this time a year ago, if I were making forecast, which I don't, that the NOL would be running out during 2015. However, once again, we have bonus depreciation
componenttext: Okay, Jason. So right now, the balance of the NOL is at $620 million. I would have predicted at this time a year ago, if I were making forecast, which I don't, that the NOL would be running out during 2015. However, once again, we have bonus depreciation this year, which is extended our runway by an additional year. And the question really becomes what is tax policy look like going forward. Will we get bonus depreciation again, if we do? I guess that, that would flush push the target of another year. So right now, my belief is that 2015 will not have material cash taxes. 2016 is a little bit up in the year for the end of the year but again, we'll see what tax policy looks like. As far as taxes is concerned, it's straightforward. A dollar that you pay in tax comes out of free cash flow. And so what we do within the limits of the tax code is we aggressively manage our exposure. So far we've been quite successful in maintaining the free cash flow profile.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we are try to give the margins get our expenses as low as possible, and we think there's more opportunity in that. But we are not willing to sacrifice any of our levels of service and in fact, we think we can improve. And if you take a look
componenttext: Well, I mean, we are try to give the margins get our expenses as low as possible, and we think there's more opportunity in that. But we are not willing to sacrifice any of our levels of service and in fact, we think we can improve. And if you take a look at our performance over the last 18 months, we've done exactly that. Now as we transitioned from being what is a traditional cable company to a connectivity company, we anticipate that our ability to reduce expenses will continue to increase except in the area of programming. The area of programming, there's very little that a cable company can do to reduce its exposure in terms of increasing programming costs, and there's no real way to continue to pass that on to the customer in a competitive environment. Now the -- so I expect on the video side, we will expect to see reducing margins, primarily due to programming expense. They -- on the other side, I expect that we will see increasing margins from the data side. The good news is with that is that the consumer values the connectivity product more than they do the video product at this point. And so that's roughly how we look at them. I'm not sure that even answers your question, but...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Craig, from my perspective, I'm obviously, not going to speak for Josh or for Ted. You'll hear about their views as to the strategic landscape, Josh is tomorrow, and I think Ted just went through his on call. But from my perspective, it's an opportuni
componenttext: And Craig, from my perspective, I'm obviously, not going to speak for Josh or for Ted. You'll hear about their views as to the strategic landscape, Josh is tomorrow, and I think Ted just went through his on call. But from my perspective, it's an opportunity to continue to look at the ecosystem and the way that each of these 3 companies fits within a rapidly changing ecosystem. It's obviously, not just the changes not just affecting Cablevision. And I feel pretty comfortable in taking this a new role because of the fact that we have a very experienced the financial team here at Cablevision. You've met a number of the individuals as of the many of the investors on this call. It's a great team. I think Brian's leadership is going to be instrumental in making sure that this is a smooth transition. But I also have to tell you, I'm still going to be here. Jim and the board have asked me to continue to play a key role at Cablevision, working with our leadership team across-the-board on the company's financial and corporate strategy and additionally, on Investor Relations. So for some period of time, you're going to be hearing my voice on these calls and at Investor Meeting sentiment forward to continuing in that role.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, the thing about it is that, the big shift here is what I said before. The consumer, if given a choice, you can either have your video product or you can have your data product, right? Now almost overwhelmingly will take the data product and the -- a
componenttext: Okay, the thing about it is that, the big shift here is what I said before. The consumer, if given a choice, you can either have your video product or you can have your data product, right? Now almost overwhelmingly will take the data product and the -- and that's a pretty big shift that the particularly as we go out to the marketplace. Now as far as what the cellular companies are suggesting, right? In terms of handoffs, et cetera, we already do handoffs and -- but not over 30 miles an hour, which basically means if you're in a car going down the, it's won't help you there. But we're very upfront with the product, and I think pretty much everybody knows that about WiFi. And our anticipation is that the technology will continue to develop. And I think that at some point event that will be included in the products set. But I think the bigger indication, the one cellular companies have to truly worry about is the one I talked about before, nobody's building connectivity using cellular. Nobody. Everybody is using WiFi. Now -- and the -- so why is that? The -- I think the answer to that is obvious, right? WiFi is much a more efficient, effective method of delivering data between a device and network and a server. And the -- and so we can listen to the people who already invested their $40 billion and defend why they invested their $40 billion. And technology is technology, science is science, and this is what it is, and I think that in my opinion, the die is cast here.

componenttext: No, I don't want to let any cats out of the bag, but I going to tell you that we're going to be very reactive to what we see, what the consumer wants. The consumer wants their connectivity first, they're a little less concerned, right, with what they're video packages are and what some of them would prefer to save money on those, we're going to be reactive to that, and we're going to continue to package our products so that we meet their needs and their demands. More to come maybe on the next call.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, as we keep stating, it's a product that passes data and also makes phone calls and texting. componenttext: Good morning. My name is Christie, and I will be your conference operator today. headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO of Cablevision; Gregg Seibert, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer; Brian Sweeney, President and incoming
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Cablevision's Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO of Cablevision; Gregg Seibert, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer; Brian Sweeney, President and incoming Chief Financial Officer; and Kristin Dolan, Chief Operating Officer. Following a discussion of the company's fourth quarter 2014 results, we will open the call for questions. If you do not have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com.
Please note the following: Today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call. On Page 7 of today's earnings release, we provide a reconciliation of operating income to adjusted operating cash flow, or AOCF. 
I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindi, and good morning. Cablevision delivered strong financial results in 2014, while continuing to transform the Optimum experience. We developed higher-quality customer relationships by offering products and services that provide superior va
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindi, and good morning. Cablevision delivered strong financial results in 2014, while continuing to transform the Optimum experience. We developed higher-quality customer relationships by offering products and services that provide superior value, provide expanded connectivity inside and outside the home and enhancing the performance of our network. Our full year 2014 financial results reflect our progress.
Total company net revenue increased nearly 4% and AOCF increased by 9% compared with 2013. Our capital expenditures were $892 million, 6% lower than 2013. Full year 2014 free cash flow was $487 million, and we declared a $0.15 per share quarterly dividend on February 24. Our fourth quarter net customer results compared favorably with the third quarter. We added data customers, despite significant competitive discounting and economic pressures in portions of our footprint. We also significantly reduced the loss of our customer relationships, even in our most competitive areas. Our results reflect a decrease in move and nonpay-related churn versus the third quarter.
During the fourth quarter, we continue to deliver strong year-over-year growth in revenue per customer. Disciplined approaches to pricing, promotional eligibility and customer credit policies are key elements of our strategy. While these policies reduced the number of our available sales opportunities, we believe they contribute to a stronger base of customers over time. We plan to continue these policies in 2015, while differentiating the value of Optimum in the marketplace.
During 2014, we introduced several new products and enhancements. Let me mention some of them -- of the more notable initiatives: We introduced 2 new Optimum Online speed tiers. We enhanced our TV to GO video experience by integrating more than 50 networks into the Optimum app. We improved our Multi-Room DVR by increasing simultaneous recordings to 15 shows. We also signed our first advertising clients to our new data and analytics service. In addition to these product enhancements, we continued to improve our customer service activity. 2014 total customer service phone calls declined by nearly 16%.
Trouble call and truck rolls declined 21% each as compared with 2013. These achievements reflect the contributions of our nearly 15,000 employees. In 2014, we continued to invest in our people and transform our culture to one that is more performance based. We did this through new recognition training and development programs as well as a new nonexecutive performance bonus plan.
And finally, let's discuss our WiFi initiatives.
In 2014, we launched our newest WiFi smart router. We also surpassed our goal of reaching more than 1 million Optimum WiFi access points within our service area. We continue to see remarkable growth in Optimum WiFi usage. During the fourth quarter, our customers used more than 4x the amount of data than during the fourth quarter of 2013.
WiFi is a critical part of our product strategy and one of our most important strategic assets. As I have noted before, we plan to continue to innovate in this area, which brings me to Freewheel, our most recent effort to monetize our investment in WiFi. Freewheel is the first all-WiFi device from a cable provider. It is available nationwide and delivers unlimited data talk and text. It works anywhere in the world where you are connected to WiFi. Freewheel is backed by our carrier-grade Optimum WiFi network, with 1.1 million hotspots in the tri-state area. 
Today, Optimum WiFi customers pass an average of more than 6 gigabytes of data per month. That is nearly 3x more data than the most commonly purchased data plans from cellular providers. Against this backdrop, we believe Freewheel will be the beginning of a disruptive force to the cellular industry.
As a company, we are solidifying our position as our customers prefer connectivity company. Freewheel is a natural progression of this strategy. This the first in a series of new products and services, which we intend to launch in order to better serve our customers' needs. 
For 3 years, we have been improving our relationships with our customers. Today, service quality has become the key differentiator of the Optimum experience, and we remain committed to being the best service provider in the industry. In 2015, as we continue this important work, we expect to introduce additional innovative products and repack certain of our current offerings. Our goal is to meet and exceed the rapidly evolving demands of our customers.
With that, I will now turn the call over to Gregg Seibert.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim, and good morning. Total company fourth quarter net revenue increased 3% and AOCF declined by 3.4% as compared with the prior year period. Capital expenditures were $262 million compared with $211 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. Four
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim, and good morning. Total company fourth quarter net revenue increased 3% and AOCF declined by 3.4% as compared with the prior year period. Capital expenditures were $262 million compared with $211 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. Fourth quarter free cash flow was $88 million.
During the quarter, we gained nearly 4,000 net high-speed data customers. Customer relationships and voice customers both decreased by 11,000 and video customers declined by 34,000.
Fourth quarter average monthly revenue per customer increased by nearly $8 to $155.20 as compared with the prior year period. This increase is consistent with our pricing strategies and principally reflects recent rate initiatives, our disciplined approach to promotional eligibility and higher advertising revenue.
Fourth quarter total cable revenue increased by 3.1%, reflecting the increase in revenue per customer, which was partially offset by fewer customer relationships.
As compared with 2013, fourth quarter cable advertising revenue increased by 9%, driven primarily by increased political- and issue-related spending. This growth was offset in part by lower banking and leisure spending. Our audience data and addressable advertising campaigns contributed to this growth, and we are successfully attracting new national advertisers for advanced advertising and measurement capabilities.
Cable AOCF declined 4.6% in the fourth quarter as compared with the prior year period. This primarily reflects the impact of fewer customers and higher programming, employee-related and marketing costs as well as higher legal expenses and other fees. This was partially offset by revenue growth and lower costs associated with the decline in trouble call-related truck rolls and customer service calls.
Cable's fourth quarter AOCF margin was 30.3%. Full year 2014 AOCF margin was 31.7%, slightly higher than the prior year period comparable margin of 31.2%. Cable capital spending in the fourth quarter was $222 million, a $46 million increase from the same period in 2013. This increase reflects the timing of CPE purchases and higher spending on WiFi and support capital.
Total cable capital spending for 2014 was approximately 8% lower than the comparable 2013 level. AOCF and capital expenditures for the fourth quarter reflect modest prelaunch investments in Freewheel.
Lightpath's fourth quarter revenue increased 6.2% and AOCF increased 10% over the prior year period. These increases reflect revenue growth in Ethernet-based services, partially offset by the continuing decline in legacy TDM-based services.
During 2014, Lightpath's network expanded to approximately 7,400 buildings, an increase of 600 connections. Lightpath also added 100 Gigabit Optical Transport Services and managed video conferencing to its suite of products. Lightpath's expanding product portfolio and nearly ubiquitous footprint continue to present us with a great opportunity to grow into the mid- and large-enterprise base. 
In our other segment, fourth quarter revenue was essentially flat and the AOCF deficit improved by 4.5%. These results principally reflect higher advertising revenue at News 12, partially offset by lower advertising revenue at Newsday. AOCF also reflects reduced expenditures of certain other businesses.
We continue to focus on transforming the Optimum experience and strengthening our position as the market's premier connectivity company by investing in our network, products and employees, while continuing to respond to the evolving marketplace with innovative products, such as Freewheel.
Looking forward to 2015, we currently anticipate that total company AOCF and CapEx, including incremental expenditures for Freewheel, will be substantially similar to our 2014 results. However, this is a dynamic business, and we anticipate updating our guidance as the year progresses.
Now turning to the company's financial position. The company's fourth quarter consolidated cash position was $850 million and net debt was $7.9 billion. We had a -- we had $1.43 billion undrawn and available under the $1.5 billion revolving credit facility at CSC Holdings as of the end of 2014.
During 2014, we executed a number of successful financing transactions, which extended our maturities, strengthened our balance sheet and improved our strong liquidity position, while funding our quarterly dividend. We plan to apply our 2015 free cash flow in a similar manner.
In May, we issued $750 million of 5.25% senior notes due 2024 at par, which was the lowest bond issuance coupon in the company's history. The net proceeds and a portion of our cash on hand were used to repay $750 million of our Term Loan B credit facility.
Later in the year, CSC Holdings made a $200 million voluntary repayment of its Term Loan B facility. This transaction results in cash interest savings over the remaining term of the facility as well as improving our debt maturity profile by reducing our 2020 debt maturities. We also use cash on hand to opportunistically repurchase approximately $37 million of Cablevision's senior notes. This was executed at an average price below par and will generate cash interest savings over the term of the notes.
At December 31, the company's consolidated net leverage ratio was 4.5x. The CSC Holdings Restricted Group bank leverage ratio was 3.1x.
In calculating our total company leverage ratio, AOCF is determined using latest quarter annualized AOCF. As a result, our leverage ratios are more sensitive to changes in quarterly AOCF than they would be if our leverage was measured based on trailing 12-month AOCF.
We did not repurchase shares of Cablevision stock during 2014. We have approximately $450 million of remaining stock repurchase authorization.
Finally, in June, Charter Communications reached a settlement with the Montana Department of Revenue related to a property tax dispute that was originally litigated during our ownership of Bresnan Communications. As a result, during the fourth quarter, we received substantially all of the approximately $6.6 million in cash that we expect to receive from Charter as a result of this settlement.
Operator, we're now prepared to open the call for questions.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
