componenttext: Your next question comes from Mike McCormack of Jefferies.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gregg, just if you could think more about on the CapEx side. You've had pretty elevated CPE on some of the project work you've been undertaking. And not to sort of shed light on what '15 projects look like, but I guess we were sort of looking at it and sa
componenttext: Gregg, just if you could think more about on the CapEx side. You've had pretty elevated CPE on some of the project work you've been undertaking. And not to sort of shed light on what '15 projects look like, but I guess we were sort of looking at it and saying, "Why shouldn't that be a lower number in '15?" And then if you could, maybe just a comment on cash taxes for 2015.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let's start with the cash tax comment. Thankfully, we have bonus depreciation again. So I do not anticipate that we'll run through the NOL in 2015. So cash taxes will be quite light yet again. In terms of the capital side of the equation, Mike, you
componenttext: Sure. Let's start with the cash tax comment. Thankfully, we have bonus depreciation again. So I do not anticipate that we'll run through the NOL in 2015. So cash taxes will be quite light yet again. In terms of the capital side of the equation, Mike, you call out the CPE number, and we had an increase in CPE in the fourth quarter. But a lot of what happens with CPE, as you know, is timing of expenditures. We ended up with additional purchases of boxes, of managed routers, some remotes in the fourth quarter, but it's not necessarily CPE that will keep capital expenditures sort of roughly at these levels. We continue to invest in WiFi. We continue across the board to invest in our network, and we're going to continue those efforts. As you'll recall from a few years ago, there was a period where we didn't feel the plant was up to the capability it needed to be up to. So that's not going to -- as we've said many times, that's not going to happen again. We're going to keep the level of investment up to a point where we can truly realize this ambition of being the premier connectivity company in the New York marketplace.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gregg, I'm sorry, just on the other thing on the SG&A, looked like a pretty good sequential increase. Is there seasonality there? And maybe just if you could size up the employee-related impact that would be great.
componenttext: Gregg, I'm sorry, just on the other thing on the SG&A, looked like a pretty good sequential increase. Is there seasonality there? And maybe just if you could size up the employee-related impact that would be great.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what I'd actually do is -- I want to talk just a tiny bit about the gross margin items in the quarter, because we had a couple of items that jump off the sheet, which you'll see in the K. Because, for example, our cable recurring revenue was up $40
componenttext: Well, what I'd actually do is -- I want to talk just a tiny bit about the gross margin items in the quarter, because we had a couple of items that jump off the sheet, which you'll see in the K. Because, for example, our cable recurring revenue was up $40 million in the quarter. Our programming costs were up $25 million. So you would normally expect more of a margin improvement under that type of scenario, but we had $10 million of severance in the quarter. Severance in the fourth quarter of 2013 was a below-the-AOCF line item because of the fact that we had a formal restructuring. This year, it's not. So that's a $10 million delta. And advertising expense was up by $13 million year-over-year. Some of that was related to the Freewheel launch. And those 2 items and some additional fees associated with the launch of Freewheel had an impact on the quarter. So those were sort of the bigger items. There was some increase in compensation costs, but that's something that happens fairly frequently in the fourth quarter as we true up the ultimate incentive programs to the actual results for the year.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jessica Reif Cohen with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jessica Reif Cohen with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have 3, if that's okay. The first is for Jim, Gregg and Kristin. Jim, you said at the beginning of the call that WiFi is one of your most important strategic assets. Obviously, you're starting with Freewheel. Can you give us your longer-term -- like how
componenttext: I have 3, if that's okay. The first is for Jim, Gregg and Kristin. Jim, you said at the beginning of the call that WiFi is one of your most important strategic assets. Obviously, you're starting with Freewheel. Can you give us your longer-term -- like how you're thinking about things over the longer term?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mean about WiFi? Or just overall about the company?
componenttext: You mean about WiFi? Or just overall about the company?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, if you want to do both, that's fine. I meant specifically WiFi, because you said it was one of the most important strategic assets.
componenttext: Well, if you want to do both, that's fine. I meant specifically WiFi, because you said it was one of the most important strategic assets.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, sure. And the -- I mean, WiFi is connectivity and connectivity on a wireless basis. And what we're seeing in the marketplace and what we believe is the, for lack of a better term, the wave of the future, is more and more and more reliance on WiFi by
componenttext: Okay, sure. And the -- I mean, WiFi is connectivity and connectivity on a wireless basis. And what we're seeing in the marketplace and what we believe is the, for lack of a better term, the wave of the future, is more and more and more reliance on WiFi by our customers because their use of data is going up. But also, for instance, if you went to the Consumer Electronics Show this year, the -- I don't think there was hardly anything on the floor that wasn't connected using a WiFi device. I didn't see one thing, by the way, being connected using a cellular device. The -- what all of this tells us is that connectivity, particularly on a wireless basis, is going to become more and more important to our consumers. We want to be the company that provides that connectivity. We want to be the company that's seen as being the best at providing that connectivity. Now we think that, that's sort of the first part of the wave. The second part is, is that there are products and services that will go along with that strategic position, the first of which you've just seen, which is Freewheel. But there will be others. And we feel that we will be poised and ready to take advantage of the strategic position that we've created by investing in WiFi in order to do that. So other than that, from the company point of view, I would say that the other thing that we see, which is really very closely related, is that connectivity has surpassed video as the primary product for a company like ours. And the -- and we need to continue to strategize our product offerings to reflect that, with different packaging, et cetera, which is something I think we will do in 2015.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then one for Gregg. Gregg, just one more specific, but you mentioned that there was an increase in the build-out. I think you said 600 buildings. Is there a way that you can size to how big the opportunity? As you continue to increase buildings
componenttext: Great. And then one for Gregg. Gregg, just one more specific, but you mentioned that there was an increase in the build-out. I think you said 600 buildings. Is there a way that you can size to how big the opportunity? As you continue to increase buildings, is there like a potential market size that you can address?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the Lightpath side, Jessica, the building talent matters a lot, but it matters in 2 directions. One of the -- when I first started working closely with Dave Pistacchio, who runs Lightpath, a couple of years ago, one of the key attributes of the busines
componenttext: On the Lightpath side, Jessica, the building talent matters a lot, but it matters in 2 directions. One of the -- when I first started working closely with Dave Pistacchio, who runs Lightpath, a couple of years ago, one of the key attributes of the business at that point in time was that we were spending roughly $0.35 in capital for every $1 of revenue that we were generating. And I think that we had a very high AOCF margin in that business, which was great. But when you're putting so much back into capital, the free cash flow profile of the business is not as attractive as the free cash flow profile is in cable. And one of the things that we were doing was we were lighting a lot of additional buildings and not getting the same type of sell-through, or at least the sort of targeted type of sell-through, for additional tenants in already wired buildings. So I think what Dave and his team are doing now is they're selectively lighting new buildings when they have a new anchor tenant. But one of the reasons the margins have been expanding, particularly the cash flow margin, in that business has been the fact that we're doing a better job of making sure that we're marketing through secondary tenants in those buildings. When you don't have to light a new building in the Lightpath business in order to generate incremental revenue, the cash flow characteristics of that account becomes substantially better. I'd argue lots of growth opportunity for Lightpath. We mentioned some of the new managed services they are providing, and lots of room in the footprint. It's still a very fragmented business of which we have a minority share, and my expectation is that we're going to keep building that share.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then the last one for Kristin. So you guys -- obviously, it's an advertising question. The -- I just was wondering if you could give us some color on the progress you've had in selling data. And how willing are advertisers to use that data vers
componenttext: Great. And then the last one for Kristin. So you guys -- obviously, it's an advertising question. The -- I just was wondering if you could give us some color on the progress you've had in selling data. And how willing are advertisers to use that data versus, say, Nielsen? And I guess, the second part of the question would be, you've been building and building and building targeted advertising, where do you think you are in the process? Is it where you want to be? Or is there still like a runway?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, we continue to be very enthusiastic. I think last quarter, despite a decline in local TV ad markets of 10%, our ad revenue grew by 9%. So that is definitely something we're enthusiastic about. We do a significant amount of development work. And
componenttext: Well, yes, we continue to be very enthusiastic. I think last quarter, despite a decline in local TV ad markets of 10%, our ad revenue grew by 9%. So that is definitely something we're enthusiastic about. We do a significant amount of development work. And now that Dibble is here, we think more about integrating more data, like we did with Time Warner Cable and utilizing the data and analytics that we derive from that data to create new products and services. I think there's a lot more room to grow. I don't know if that answers your question.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, in selling the data, like how willing are people to -- how willing are your customers to use that versus, let's say, Nielsen?
componenttext: I mean, in selling the data, like how willing are people to -- how willing are your customers to use that versus, let's say, Nielsen?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think I can speak directly to Nielsen. What I will say is the value of census level, which is household data down to individual homes versus an extrapolation. And we always talk about the fact that Nielsen has 365 people meters in the entire New Y
componenttext: I don't think I can speak directly to Nielsen. What I will say is the value of census level, which is household data down to individual homes versus an extrapolation. And we always talk about the fact that Nielsen has 365 people meters in the entire New York metro footprint, which doesn't even equate to the amount of channels that we offer, shows a big difference of us being able to monitor every single channel tune in real-time for every single set-top across our entire footprint. So if you look at 365 boxes to indicate activity versus 7 million set-tops, I think you can kind of get a sense of why the advertisers are interested and why it matters.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Isn't it more important from the advertiser perspective than actually selling the data, in terms of how you're optimizing packages for a lot of our customers and using up a lot of dayparts that otherwise wouldn't be used up?
componenttext: Isn't it more important from the advertiser perspective than actually selling the data, in terms of how you're optimizing packages for a lot of our customers and using up a lot of dayparts that otherwise wouldn't be used up?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the long tail content, nontraditional dayparts, the value of cable overall, it's -- there's a lot of different tails to this, and all of them are positive and we're enthusiastic about all of them.
componenttext: Yes, the long tail content, nontraditional dayparts, the value of cable overall, it's -- there's a lot of different tails to this, and all of them are positive and we're enthusiastic about all of them.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Amy Yong of Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Amy Yong of Macquarie.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions. You spent a lot of time talking about WiFi. Do you expect that you could actually increase your market share outside of the current footprint? My second question is more for Gregg. As you look into 2015, you gave a lot of AOCF and free cash
componenttext: Two questions. You spent a lot of time talking about WiFi. Do you expect that you could actually increase your market share outside of the current footprint? My second question is more for Gregg. As you look into 2015, you gave a lot of AOCF and free cash flow guidance, at what point could you actually tap down on the buyback?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take the buyback question first, which is at this point in time, we continue to have our $0.15 per share quarterly dividend. That's a very attractive return of capital for our shareholders. And at this point, we're looking at that really as the
componenttext: Well, I'll take the buyback question first, which is at this point in time, we continue to have our $0.15 per share quarterly dividend. That's a very attractive return of capital for our shareholders. And at this point, we're looking at that really as the primary return of capital. The additional free cash flow that we generated above and beyond the dividend requirement last year was for the most part used for debt reduction. And I think that we're going to continue to be prudent in the way that we run our leverage and maturity profiles. So I think that to the extent we're generating free cash flow in excess of the dividend, it is much more likely that you will see us use that free cash flow to pay down additional debt rather than to repurchase shares at this point. But again, if there was a market event, if there was -- we'll continue to be opportunistic, and that's one of the reasons we keep the share repurchase program in place.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: As far as going outside of our footprint, the -- I assume you're talking about Freewheel, because the -- as far as the network and the cable systems go, we certainly have no plans to go out and overbuild anybody and -- because we don't think they work. Bu
componenttext: As far as going outside of our footprint, the -- I assume you're talking about Freewheel, because the -- as far as the network and the cable systems go, we certainly have no plans to go out and overbuild anybody and -- because we don't think they work. But the Freewheel is available across the United States and actually across the world, and we are seeing uses for the product outside of our footprint. In fact -- Kristin, you want to talk about Europe, or...?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're seeing some interest -- really enthusiastic interest from expats and from people who travel frequently outside the country, because they're able to maintain a U.S. phone number, they don't incur any roaming charges when they're on WiFi, eith
componenttext: Yes, so we're seeing some interest -- really enthusiastic interest from expats and from people who travel frequently outside the country, because they're able to maintain a U.S. phone number, they don't incur any roaming charges when they're on WiFi, either in their hotel or particularly in the U.K., where there's a lot of, of WiFi available and throughout Europe. So the idea of having a flat rate U.S. sort of satphone that they can use to conduct all their U.S. business is one of the sort of interesting opportunities for us that we've uncovered as we started rolling out Freewheel. So we think there's more opportunity there, particularly in Europe and also in the Caribbean.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jason Bazinet of Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jason Bazinet of Citi.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you guys had about $935 million of federal gross NOLs at the end of '13. I was just wondering if you could update us on where those are at year-end '14. And then when do you expect to become a full cash taxpayer, what year? And is it important to
componenttext: I think you guys had about $935 million of federal gross NOLs at the end of '13. I was just wondering if you could update us on where those are at year-end '14. And then when do you expect to become a full cash taxpayer, what year? And is it important to you to either minimize or not pay sizable federal income taxes in the long term?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Jason, so right now, the balance of the NOL is at $620 million. I would have predicted at this time a year ago, if I were making forecasts, which I don't, that the NOL would be running out during 2015. However, once again, we have bonus depreciation
componenttext: Okay, Jason, so right now, the balance of the NOL is at $620 million. I would have predicted at this time a year ago, if I were making forecasts, which I don't, that the NOL would be running out during 2015. However, once again, we have bonus depreciation this year, which has extended our runway by an additional year. And the question really becomes what does tax policy look like going forward? Will we get bonus depreciation again? If we do, my guess is that, that would push the target out another year. So right now, my belief is that 2015 will not have material cash taxes, 2016 is a little bit up in the air toward the end of the year. But again, we'll see what tax policy looks like. As far as taxes are concerned, it's very straightforward. A dollar that you pay in tax comes out of free cash flow. And so what we do within the limits of the tax code is we aggressively manage our exposure. So far, we've been quite successful in maintaining the free cash flow profile.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Craig Moffett of MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Craig Moffett of MoffettNathanson.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two, if I could. First, I guess, Jimmy or Kristin, can you just talk about how you think about strategically the push and pull of trying to balance margins on the one hand and trying to sustain subscriber growth on the other, or at least subscriber stabil
componenttext: Two, if I could. First, I guess, Jimmy or Kristin, can you just talk about how you think about strategically the push and pull of trying to balance margins on the one hand and trying to sustain subscriber growth on the other, or at least subscriber stability on the other, and how you might -- how you make those decisions? And then second -- first, congratulations to both Gregg and Brian. Gregg, could you just talk a little bit about your new role and what it is you hope to accomplish in the new role that's spanning the different organizations?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim or Kristin, would you like to go first...
componenttext: Jim or Kristin, would you like to go first...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, he says Jimmy...
componenttext: Well, he says Jimmy...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not Kristy.
componenttext: Not Kristy.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And I'm not quite sure I completely understand your question, Craig. I mean, the -- you want to know how we balance margin against subscriber...
componenttext: Right. And I'm not quite sure I completely understand your question, Craig. I mean, the -- you want to know how we balance margin against subscriber...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Against subscriber growth. How do you think about raising prices in a way that sustains your margins but may also hurt your subscriber metrics? And how do you prioritize between those 2 things?
componenttext: Against subscriber growth. How do you think about raising prices in a way that sustains your margins but may also hurt your subscriber metrics? And how do you prioritize between those 2 things?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, the -- we try and keep the margins right. We're trying to keep our expenses as low as possible, and we think there's more opportunity in that. But we are not willing to sacrifice any of our levels of service. And in fact, we think we can imp
componenttext: Well, I mean, the -- we try and keep the margins right. We're trying to keep our expenses as low as possible, and we think there's more opportunity in that. But we are not willing to sacrifice any of our levels of service. And in fact, we think we can improve them. And I think if you take a look at our performance over the last 18 months, we've done exactly that. Now the -- now as we transition from being what is a traditional cable company to a connectivity company, we anticipate that our ability to reduce expenses will continue to increase, except in the area of programming. The area of programming, there's very little that a cable company can do to reduce its exposure in terms of increasing programming costs, and there's no real way to continue to pass that on to the customer in a competitive environment. Now the -- so I expect on the video side, we will expect to see reducing margins, primarily due to programming expense, that the -- on the other side, I expect that we will see increasing margins from the data side. The good news is with that is that the consumer values the connectivity product more than they do the video product at this point. And so that's roughly how we look at them. I'm not sure that even answers your question, but...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Craig, from my perspective, I'm obviously not going to speak for Josh or for Tad. You'll hear about their views as to the strategic landscape. Josh is tomorrow and I think Tad just went through his on the MSG call. But from my perspective, it's an opp
componenttext: And Craig, from my perspective, I'm obviously not going to speak for Josh or for Tad. You'll hear about their views as to the strategic landscape. Josh is tomorrow and I think Tad just went through his on the MSG call. But from my perspective, it's an opportunity to continue to look at the ecosystem and the way that each of these 3 companies fits within a rapidly changing ecosystem. It's obviously not just -- changes not just affecting Cablevision. And I feel pretty comfortable taking this new role because of the fact that we have a very experienced financial team here at Cablevision. You've met a number of the individuals, as have many of the investors on this call. It's a great team. I think Brian's leadership is going to be instrumental in making sure that this is a smooth transition. But I also have to tell you, I'm still going to be here. Jim and the board have asked me to continue to play a key role at Cablevision, working with the leadership team across the board on the company's financial and corporate strategy and additionally on Investor Relations. So for some period of time, you're going to be hearing my voice on these calls and at Investor Meetings, and I look forward to continuing in that role.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions, one on Freewheel and one on video. Jim, you alluded to some new packaging, I think, on the video side in your prepared remarks. But as you know, the programmers sort of make you carry everything. So just wondering if you have some color you
componenttext: Two questions, one on Freewheel and one on video. Jim, you alluded to some new packaging, I think, on the video side in your prepared remarks. But as you know, the programmers sort of make you carry everything. So just wondering if you have some color you can add to that, how you might think about repackaging video and what the strategy is there in terms of addressing maybe a different kind of customer set than you've had in the past. And then on the Freewheel side, the -- all the carriers who just spent, whatever it was, $40 billion on spectrum would claim WiFi has QoS issues and handoff issues. Now that you have a product in the market, can you talk about how the consumer experience is? Are you finding people are happy with the service? And do you have a plan for handoff, where WiFi can become a true replacement for cellular in terms of moving around?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll handle it, I think. I'll say if I need help. So in terms of WiFi, I think it's a little early on the customer experience. We do have some early indications that customers are finding the product to do what we said it was going to do, and that they're
componenttext: I'll handle it, I think. I'll say if I need help. So in terms of WiFi, I think it's a little early on the customer experience. We do have some early indications that customers are finding the product to do what we said it was going to do, and that they're enjoying it. I hear a lot of anecdotal information from individual customers, et cetera, users of the product, that we find very positive and reinforcing. But I don't think we're ready yet to start saying -- to start defining the user experience, and we don't have enough metrics in the house yet to do that. So -- and your other question...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just on video packaging, how you think about changing that.
componenttext: Just on video packaging, how you think about changing that.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, yes, yes. Okay. So the thing about it is, is that the big shift here is what I said before. The consumer would, if given the choice, would -- if you said, you can either have your video product or you can have your data product, right, now almo
componenttext: Okay. Yes, yes, yes. Okay. So the thing about it is, is that the big shift here is what I said before. The consumer would, if given the choice, would -- if you said, you can either have your video product or you can have your data product, right, now almost overwhelmingly will take the data product. And the -- and that's a pretty big shift that the -- particularly as we go out to the marketplace. Now as far as what the cellular companies are suggesting, right, in terms of handoffs, et cetera, we already do, do handoffs, and the -- but not over 30 miles an hour, which basically means if you're in a car going down the LIE, it won't help you there. But we're very upfront with that with the product, and I think pretty much everybody knows that about WiFi. And our anticipation is that technology will continue to develop. And I think that at some point, even that will be included in the product set. But I think the bigger indication, and the one cellular companies have to truly worry about is the one I talked about before: nobody's building connectivity using cellular. Nobody. Everybody is using WiFi. Now -- and the -- so why is that? The -- I think the answer to that is obvious, right? WiFi is a much more efficient, effective method of delivering data between a device, a network and a server. And the -- and so we can listen to the people who already invested their $40 billion and defend why they invested their $40 billion. But technology is technology, science is science, and this is what it is. And I think that, in my opinion, the die is cast here, so...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, is there an opportunity on the video side to do smaller packages, based on your contracts, things like sort of skinny video or maybe some kind of HBO over-the-top. Are you looking at any of those opportunities?
componenttext: Yes, is there an opportunity on the video side to do smaller packages, based on your contracts, things like sort of skinny video or maybe some kind of HBO over-the-top. Are you looking at any of those opportunities?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't want to let any cats out of the bag, but I will tell you that we're going to be very reactive to what we see what the consumer wants. The consumer wants their connectivity first. They're a little less concerned, right, with what they're video pack
componenttext: I don't want to let any cats out of the bag, but I will tell you that we're going to be very reactive to what we see what the consumer wants. The consumer wants their connectivity first. They're a little less concerned, right, with what they're video packages are and what some of them would prefer to save money on those. We're going to be reactive to that, and we're going to continue to package our products so that we meet their needs and their demands. More to come, maybe the next call.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll say one thing, too. If you're talking about QoS, think about QoS on streaming video and compare your cellular experience to your WiFi experience, because that's what we're chasing. We're not chasing QoS on a phone call.
componenttext: Maybe I'll say one thing, too. If you're talking about QoS, think about QoS on streaming video and compare your cellular experience to your WiFi experience, because that's what we're chasing. We're not chasing QoS on a phone call.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from James Ratcliffe of Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from James Ratcliffe of Buckingham Research.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two, if I could. One is in housekeeping. Why did homes passed tick down in 4Q? Is there something seasonal or anything else going on? And secondly, with all the debate around net neutrality, I mean, assuming the rules that go into effect, in line with the
componenttext: Two, if I could. One is in housekeeping. Why did homes passed tick down in 4Q? Is there something seasonal or anything else going on? And secondly, with all the debate around net neutrality, I mean, assuming the rules that go into effect, in line with the chairman's comments and proposal from earlier this month, is there anything you do differently in your business versus a world where we are, continue to have no net neutrality rules on the books?

componenttext: And as far as net neutrality goes, the -- we're never -- I mean, we're -- like any other business, we're -- the idea of more regulation is never great for us. But to be honest, we don't really see, at least what the chairman's been discussing, as having any real effect on our business. And so therefore, we're sort of neutral.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, as we keep stating, it's a product that passes data and also makes phone calls and texting. But we did nearly 1 billion sessions over WiFi in the fourth quarter, and our average customer is utilizing more than 6 gigabits of data a month. From
componenttext: Yes, I mean, as we keep stating, it's a product that passes data and also makes phone calls and texting. But we did nearly 1 billion sessions over WiFi in the fourth quarter, and our average customer is utilizing more than 6 gigabits of data a month. From where we sit, data is what matters, WiFi was built for data. And we don't see any indications that people's thirst -- aggressive thirst for data is going to decline. So we're planning for the future. We're not chasing -- as I said before, we're not chasing the cellular market to be a mobile phone provider. That's just not what the strategy for this product is about.

It continues to be a core product for us, but it's going to be a dynamic budget. And I'm not really comfortable breaking it into components at this point in the year.

componenttext: Just quickly, so now that you're saying access is the most important product, or I assume that you're more inclined to support over-the-top and just be more agnostic on that, and is that what we could expect to see a little bit more aggressively? And then looking at the Optimum Lightpath, what tactics are you using to get the additional tenants in the building? That's been a little bit elusive for other fiber providers that have wired up buildings. How are you having success there where some of your competitors have not?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think what Dave and his team are doing on the Lightpath side is they have made substantial changes in the sales organization. There have also been substantial changes made in the incentive compensation or commission structure for the sales organization.
componenttext: I think what Dave and his team are doing on the Lightpath side is they have made substantial changes in the sales organization. There have also been substantial changes made in the incentive compensation or commission structure for the sales organization. You know, 2 years ago, I would say that the bulk of our sales effort within Lightpath was concentrated on Long Island. We're a Long Island-based company. And yet, quite a bit of the growth was occurring in New Jersey and Connecticut. Have been some pretty significant shifts there. And as we have shifted resources from one part of the footprint to another part of the footprint, we've also changed the structure, changed the incentive, changed the sales management. And I think it's all just basic blocking and tackling within the building. So I'd love to tell you there's a specific silver bullet that could be applied across the industry, but I really think it's just that basic blocking and tackling that makes the difference.

componenttext: I think to your question about access, we already have 100 networks accessible through our Optimum app. Our Optimum app gets a ton of usage. And then when you combine that with the WiFi backbone, it's really -- that's the vision for us with our customers to access any product anywhere, anytime within the footprint.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Cablevision's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO; Kristin Dolan, Chief Moderating Officer; Brian Sweeney, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Gregg Seibert,
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Cablevision's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO; Kristin Dolan, Chief Moderating Officer; Brian Sweeney, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Gregg Seibert, Vice Chairman. Jim will start off the call, and then Kristen will provide an operational and product updates. Brian will review our financial results, followed by Gregg, who will discuss our capital position and capital allocation strategy prior to moderating our Q&A. If you do not have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com. 
Please note the following. Today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call. On Page 6 of today's earnings release, we provide a reconciliation of operating income to adjusted operating cash flow or AOCF. 
I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindi, and good morning. Cablevision is off to a solid start in 2015. Consolidated revenue grew more than 2% and AOCF increased nearly 5% compared with the first quarter of 2014. Our capital expenditures were $167 million, free cash flow was $4
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindi, and good morning. Cablevision is off to a solid start in 2015. Consolidated revenue grew more than 2% and AOCF increased nearly 5% compared with the first quarter of 2014. Our capital expenditures were $167 million, free cash flow was $49 million and we declared a $0.15 per share dividend on May 1.
Turning to our strategic. We remain focused on advancing our position as New York's premier connectivity company. Today's digital consumer expects to be connected all the time on all devices wherever they are. And cablevision's path for continued success is to stay ahead of these changes and we are determined to do just that. 
To achieve this on the product side, we have been advancing connectivity to a broader set of consumers and providing innovative products and service options. We are taking bold steps to connect the customers in new ways. For example, in February, we launched Freewheel, this is our new WiFi-only phone service with unlimited data talk and text, free from the high cost and data limits imposed by cellular providers. Freewheel leverages the power of our robust WiFi network. It also helps monetize our investment in WiFi. 
In March, we announced agreement to make HBO Now available through the Internet to our high-speed data customers. Cablevision is currently the only cable provider to offer the full suite of HBO products. Just last week, we were the first cable or satellite operator to announce plans to distribute Hulu to our customers. We also recently launched Core Carter packages that target a new generation of consumers. These offers provide alternatives for those who prefer to access video content through the Internet. Packages are available at different price ranges and all include a digital antenna at no charge for over-the-air TV. This allows customers to bypass the big bundle and still watch broadcast television as well as over-the-top content. 
In summary, the company is changing and these new initiatives are few examples of our evolution. Going forward, you will see more products and services that focus on flexibility as we reimagine Cablevision and its place in the market. 
With that, let me now turn the call over to Kristin Dolan, for an personal product -- operational and products review.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. First quarter net customer results generally compared favorably with the third and fourth quarters of 2014. We added data customers, despite significant competitive discounting and economic pressures in portions of our footprint. Our disci
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. First quarter net customer results generally compared favorably with the third and fourth quarters of 2014. We added data customers, despite significant competitive discounting and economic pressures in portions of our footprint. Our disciplined approach to pricing, promotional eligibility and customer credit policies has not wavered. We're targeting a stronger base of customers, while differentiating the value of Optimum in the marketplace. To this end, during the first quarter, we continue to deliver strong year-over-year growth and revenue per customer.
In addition to the new product offerings that Jim mentioned, let me share some other highlights. We signed several new clients for our data and analytics service. We're also working with other to provide combined insights from set-top boxes tuning data. We expanded the availability of our 51 data [ph] services known as Internet basics. This service, which we initially introduced in Newark is now available across our entire footprint.
On the office and the data spectrum, Optimum was the first cable company to introduce 1 gigabyte residential service in the tri-state area. The service launched in a new multi-tenant building in Hawken, New Jersey [ph]. This offering showcases the strength and versatility of the Optimum network. We also continue to identify ways to expand the breadth of our WiFi coverage as well as optimize speed and performance. 
As we look ahead, our 2015 WiFi growth plan includes deploying access points in high data usage areas. Additionally, ongoing investments in our WiFi network will continue to enhance the value of our Freewheel service.
We continue to be service and reliability key differentiators of the Optimum experience. First quarter total customer service phone calls declined by 12% and trouble call truck rolls decreased 21%, each as compared with the prior year period. We're pleased with our progress in the first quarter and we'll remain highly focused on delivering superior service and enhancing our customer relationship. 
With that, let me turn to Brian Sweeney, to review our financial results.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kristin. Jim provided an overview of total company results, so now let's review our business segments. During the quarter, we gained 7,000 net high-speed data customers. Customer relationships, video and voice customers declined by 6,000, 28,
componenttext:
Thank you, Kristin. Jim provided an overview of total company results, so now let's review our business segments. 
During the quarter, we gained 7,000 net high-speed data customers. Customer relationships, video and voice customers declined by 6,000, 28,000 and 14,000, respectively. First quarter average monthly revenue per customer increased by more than $7 to $155.34, as compared with the prior year period. This increase is consistent with our pricing strategies and principally reflects recent rate initiatives and our disciplined approach to promotional eligibility and retention policies. 
First quarter total cable revenue increased by 2.4%, reflecting the increase in revenue per customer, which was partially offset by fewer customers. As compared with 2014, first quarter cable advertising revenue decreased by 3%, primarily due to lower gaming and spending. These declines were offset in part by higher auto and consumer spending, which benefited from addressable advertising campaign.
Cable AOCF increased 0.8% in the first quarter, as compared with the prior year period. This primarily reflects the impact of revenue growth and lower employee and customer service-related costs. This was partially offset by fewer customers and higher programming, product development and marketing costs.
Cable capital spending in the first quarter was $134 million, a $12 million decrease from the same period in 2014. This primarily reflects lower CPE spending due to the timing of set-top box and modem purchases, partially offset by continued deployment of our smart routers and further investment in our network to support our new data offering and WiFi expansion. 
Lightpath's first quarter revenue increased 5% and AOCF grew nearly 13%, as compared with the prior year period. These increases reflect revenue growth in the Internet-based services, partially offset by continuing decline in legacy TDM-based services.
Lightpath has been expanding beyond its traditional bowl voice data and Internet service offerings also provide managed services with a lineup that is grown to include audio and web conferencing, backup, hosted voice and other services. Additionally, Lightpath has increased its focused on medium-size businesses. Lightpath's growing product portfolio and increasing presence in these markets provides us with an attractive opportunity to grow in the mid to large enterprise space.
In our other segment, first quarter revenue was essentially flat and the AOCF deficit improved by nearly 24%. These results principally reflect higher advertising revenue at News 12, partially offset by lower advertising revenue at Newsday. AOCF also reflects a reduction in expenses at Newsday due to lower operating costs and the termination of a distribution agreement, along with reduced expenses at corporate and certain other businesses. News 12's award-winning hyper-local programming and Newsday's strong editorial presence continue to resonate with our customers and provide a valuable retention tool for the company.
Before I turn it over to Gregg, I would note that our first quarter results were favorably impacted by the timing of several expense items, including marketing and employee-related costs as well as the timing of capital spending. We continue to anticipate that 2015 total company AOCF and CapEx, including incremental expenditures for Freewheel and our other product initiatives will be substantially similar to our 2014 results. However, as we've said before, this is a dynamic business and we anticipate updating our guidance as the year progresses. 
I'll now hand the call over to Gregg Seibert to discuss our capital position and capital allocation strategy.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Brian. Good morning. The company's first quarter consolidated cash position was $884 million and net debt was $7.8 billion. We have $1.43 billion undrawn and available under the $1.5 billion revolving credit facility at CSC Holdings at th
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Brian. Good morning. The company's first quarter consolidated cash position was $884 million and net debt was $7.8 billion. We have $1.43 billion undrawn and available under the $1.5 billion revolving credit facility at CSC Holdings at the end of the first quarter. 
At March 31, the company's consolidated net leverage ratio was 4.3x. The CSC Holdings Restricted group bank leverage ratio was 2.9x. We did not repurchase shares of Cablevision stock during 2015. We have approximately $450 million of remaining stock repurchase authorization.
Before we open the call for questions, I'd like to touch on the topic of capital allocation as we're frequently how we approach this. We plan to apply our 2015 free cash flow in a similar manner to 2014. Our current priority is to continue to invest in the business. We'll strive to provide the best possible for service to our customers and we are focused on investing in our network, including WiFi. We'll continue to invest in opportunities that will help us realize our ambition of being the premier connectivity company in our market. 
The second priority is to ensure that our balance sheet continues to afford us the ability to dynamically manage the business and apply our excess capital. I think it's likely that you'll see a portion of our excess cash applied to our effort to continue to delever.
Consistent with this approach, in April, we made a voluntary repayment of our CSC Holdings Term Loan B facility in the amount of $200 million. This repayment will result in cash interest savings over the term of the facility. Number three in our hierarchy is our dividend, which is our primary method of returning capital to shareholders.
Finally, as always, we will remain highly disciplined as we evaluate any other potential acquisitions and in customer opportunities. 
Operator, with that, we'd now like to open the call for questions.

componenttext: Sure. Okay. Cord cutters, I wouldn't call it reactive and I would -- what was the other called, proactive either. I think that it's just more fully sales out our product offering to our customer base. I think that all of cable companies as well as satellites companies have had issues with having very large bundles that are sometimes difficult for the customer to afford and our ability to offer products underneath that, right, has been limited, primarily limited by the programming contracts. Now we see the cord cutters package as a way of filling out that product line and being able to offer levels of service that are less expensive than the big bundle. And I think it also has an aspect where it services the new consumer, the millennial, et cetera. But I think, our primary thought is that it's filling out our product lines. Handle the...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Second question, Brian, the main drivers of our increased revenue per customer came from a combination of rate increases, but also, lower proportion of subscribers on promotion. We had a number of rate increases on January 1 of this year related to cable
componenttext: Second question, Brian, the main drivers of our increased revenue per customer came from a combination of rate increases, but also, lower proportion of subscribers on promotion. We had a number of rate increases on January 1 of this year related to cable box, an increase in our sports and TVs surcharge, as well as the pass-through of these to certain of our customers. In addition, RPC benefited from rate increases that were implemented in the second quarter of 2014 and the implementation of pass-through on voice taxes last summer, so the combination of all that led to the increase.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'm just going to follow up a little bit on the cord cutter question, because the 2 packages that we announced serve 2 different purposes. The first is really for people in economically challenges situation, so these are families that need Internet
componenttext: Okay. I'm just going to follow up a little bit on the cord cutter question, because the 2 packages that we announced serve 2 different purposes. The first is really for people in economically challenges situation, so these are families that need Internet for the kids to do their homework, or things like that. So the digital antenna plus the 51 [ph] Internet basis, plus Freewheel is rally for severely, economically challenged people, whereas, the other cord cutter package with the ultra-50 is really for people who have either been cord shavers or cord nevers, so we're addressing new behavior with that package, but it think it's important, we always point out that the majority of our customers in a acquisitions situation are coming in as Triple Play customers.

componenttext: So on your second question, free cash flow declined year-over-year, principally due to higher employee incentive payments, which negatively impacted for the quarter, which was only partially offset by the higher AOCF and lower capital spending. The significant portion of this amount was due to adding a discretionary component to our 401(k) benefit plan. This is an adjustment to freezing our defined benefit plans. And although while we have accrue regular contributions for the 401(k) during the calendar year, the discretionary contributions were paid in the first quarter of 2015.

componenttext: I thought you'd give us a range but in any case I'll -- moving along. headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a little early to tell. But I think we've been pretty vocal in our discussion about the fact that current audience measurement is broken and that, our success so far in migrating people over from just basic minimal customer data to census level, set-
componenttext: It's a little early to tell. But I think we've been pretty vocal in our discussion about the fact that current audience measurement is broken and that, our success so far in migrating people over from just basic minimal customer data to census level, set-top data has really been a positive for us and we have other MSOs who are securing the same type of data as we are. So we're looking at opportunities to hopefully change the commerce in advertising sales to something that's better for the customer and better for the advertiser.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And what's the response been from the advertisers?
componenttext: And what's the response been from the advertisers?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The advertiser love it. I mean, if you see we had our total audience application launch last week. We announced this breakthrough platform where it's advance media planning platform powered by the census level data and we had basically unheard of, we had
componenttext: The advertiser love it. I mean, if you see we had our total audience application launch last week. We announced this breakthrough platform where it's advance media planning platform powered by the census level data and we had basically unheard of, we had the top 3 advertising agencies all represented in our press release because they're so enthusiastic about the capability and the opportunity it provides them when they're selling or purchasing media for their clients that they are really supporting us. So I think that's indicative of the response in the marketplace to the capability.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: You know, Jessica, I think the product there are so much more for a marketer and a programmer in helping them strategize what their advertising campaigns are, are going to be and where they're going to place them, et cetera so much more than the quarter o
componenttext: You know, Jessica, I think the product there are so much more for a marketer and a programmer in helping them strategize what their advertising campaigns are, are going to be and where they're going to place them, et cetera so much more than the quarter of our share [ph], et cetera that, I mean, it's almost night and day. And so on that we're -- I mean, I think, our team is doing an excellent job of getting it out into the marketplace, and we look forward to this part of the business growing rather rapidly.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a real win-win for everybody for the advertisers and everybody else.
componenttext: It's a real win-win for everybody for the advertisers and everybody else.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015

componenttext: Yes. And then my last question, regarding to the cable convention tonight, tomorrow [indiscernible], one of the big themes, of course, is going to be industry consolidation. So Jim, I was just hoping maybe you could share some of your views on where the industry is going? And what, if any part, Cablevision will play in this?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think everybody was taken by surprise by the -- by what happened with Comcast, Time Warner, and the way the [indiscernible] point seems to be that everybody is just trying to figure out what they're going to do. We're part of the industry like everybody
componenttext: I think everybody was taken by surprise by the -- by what happened with Comcast, Time Warner, and the way the [indiscernible] point seems to be that everybody is just trying to figure out what they're going to do. We're part of the industry like everybody else, we're watching, we're studying it. Mr. Seibert, is  helping us design a path but there's really nothing to report yet. I mean, we just have to see how things shake out.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add to that, Jessica, if you don't mind, is when Rob spoke the other day, he talked about how they continue to improve their operation and that's been, for the past 3.5 years, our focus as well. And we, I can't say, how -- I really
componenttext: The only thing I would add to that, Jessica, if you don't mind, is when Rob spoke the other day, he talked about how they continue to improve their operation and that's been, for the past 3.5 years, our focus as well. And we, I can't say, how -- I really can't express how proud we are of the operating units and our success in repeats, in trouble calls, and phone volume and just the level of service that we're trying to provide and continue to improve upon to the customer base is a huge differentiator for us.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions, one on Freewheel, and then one on the newspaper assets. I guess, first, on Freewheel, can you just talk a little bit about some of the feedback that you're getting from your consumers, how might this product evolve over time? And should we
componenttext: Two questions, one on Freewheel, and then one on the newspaper assets. I guess, first, on Freewheel, can you just talk a little bit about some of the feedback that you're getting from your consumers, how might this product evolve over time? And should we expect this will contribute to broadband revenue? And then just on Newsday and News 12, how strategic are these assets? And just can you talk a little bit about some of the growth potential going forward?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on Freewheel, we continue to be really enthusiastic about the interest shown. At the end of the first quarter, our weekly visits, our unique weekly visits, increased 16% on average to our website. The weekly orders are increasing. Our users are m
componenttext: Sure. So on Freewheel, we continue to be really enthusiastic about the interest shown. At the end of the first quarter, our weekly visits, our unique weekly visits, increased 16% on average to our website. The weekly orders are increasing. Our users are making and receiving more than 20 calls a week and sending and receiving more than 70 text messages. And users per subscriber continues to grow. So we're very again, continue to be really bullish about WiFi and about Freewheel. On the broadband revenue question, Freewheel, as we've said all along, is really designed to improve customers understanding and their value perception associated with our WiFi network. So Freewheel is really an extension of that. I'm not sure that there's a direct correlation between broadband revenues other than improve retention on broadband through the use of Freewheel.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then on your second question, just relative to News 12 and it's how important it is to us, I think it's a very important tool for our customer base. 70% of our households tune to News 12 on a weekly basis. They've been able to do tremendous growth and
componenttext: And then on your second question, just relative to News 12 and it's how important it is to us, I think it's a very important tool for our customer base. 70% of our households tune to News 12 on a weekly basis. They've been able to do tremendous growth and advertising revenue over the last couple of years. And as local advertising and local news advertising, local broadcast advertising is going down, News 12 has been incredibly resilient and actually, been able to grow share in those areas.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question for Mr. Dolan and maybe Mr. Seibert. I applaud you guys for leading into this connectivity-centric strategy that you have. It seems to me as a smaller operator that this transition from a video-centric company to a connectivity-centric com
componenttext: Just a question for Mr. Dolan and maybe Mr. Seibert. I applaud you guys for leading into this connectivity-centric strategy that you have. It seems to me as a smaller operator that this transition from a video-centric company to a connectivity-centric company is easier in a way because you probably generate lower gross profits on your video product and some of your larger brethren in the ecosystem. And in that context, I was wondering if you would be willing to share in rough terms what your video gross profit margins are today just so we can get a sense of how easy or hard this transition will be?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're thinking about that. Hang on. You want to do that? I'm seeing a lot of nose around here.
componenttext: We're thinking about that. Hang on. You want to do that? I'm seeing a lot of nose around here.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think, the answer to that is today it still an integrated business and as a result, it's incumbent upon us to look at the profitability integrated business, but potentially, more to come today as soon as that transition.
componenttext: No. I think, the answer to that is today it still an integrated business and as a result, it's incumbent upon us to look at the profitability integrated business, but potentially, more to come today as soon as that transition.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: You know what, [indiscernible], I'm not going to give you any numbers, but directionally, I'll tell you that the video business, especially in a competitive marketplace like ours, that the -- has -- margins that are reducing. I think that -- what -- to wh
componenttext: You know what, [indiscernible], I'm not going to give you any numbers, but directionally, I'll tell you that the video business, especially in a competitive marketplace like ours, that the -- has -- margins that are reducing. I think that -- what -- to what level those are, depends a lot upon how you do accounting work. So for instance, when a truck rolls to a home, who does that accrue to? Is it the -- I don't think there are any operators out there right now that since they drive the truck roll out and say, well, you went for a set-top box so that's just video or you went for the router so that's just data, right? But I do think that directionally, you're seeing that the video product begin -- lose margin and not just amongst the little operators like us, but even some of the big operators. And our philosophy with this is essentially that we think that video is akin to the eggs and the milk in a convenience store. You have to have it, but you don't make a lot of money on it. Now connectivity is a whole another basket, it's more like the soda and chips aisle. And if you provide great connectivity because it provides great value to the consumer, you can differentiate yourself and you can charge more and the margins are good on it. So that's the thought process.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015

componenttext: I guess just following with that same theme. So as I think about how you balance the margins of your, not just your individual products, but your overall business, maybe we could return to something we talked about on the last call, which is how do you -- when you see the promotional activity from Verizon FiOS, how do you think about balancing the margins of your service with the need to sustain subscriber growth? How price-sensitive are your customers so you make that the price volume trade-off in the optimal way?

componenttext: Yes, I mean, we always say we don't on Verizon pricing or activity but one thing I will comment on this is just the level of service that we're providing and the customer response to that. And we to a significant amount of win-backs every year and we really focus on why people are coming back and it's not just about price. And it's -- so we focused on delivering a good product at a great value and not apologizing for pricing and sticking through our guns on that going down the promotional path and we're seeing a lot of these initiatives start to take hold with our customer base.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: As we look forward, is this about the balance then, should we assume that sort of, right now, it looks like you're getting most of your growth from AOCF or from a revenue per account growth, but not much growth now in units. Is that kind of what you're ki
componenttext: As we look forward, is this about the balance then, should we assume that sort of, right now, it looks like you're getting most of your growth from AOCF or from a revenue per account growth, but not much growth now in units. Is that kind of what you're kind of optimizing for at this point?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Craig, it's a long-term plan here and one of the keys for us was to reduce the number of customers that were coming back for constant promotional activity. I think what you've seen over the last year is the subscriber metrics on the video side have declin
componenttext: Craig, it's a long-term plan here and one of the keys for us was to reduce the number of customers that were coming back for constant promotional activity. I think what you've seen over the last year is the subscriber metrics on the video side have declined. You've seen, as you pointed out, the ARPU go up pretty substantially. This is a long game, and I don't think you should necessarily expect to see a continuation of any one trend. You should expect to see us dynamically manage the way that the business operates.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- I might go further a step further than that and actually, what your because I've thought about this. I do think that you will see that trend to some level. The -- because the, particularly when you're adding core cutter package, et cetera, we
componenttext: Well, the -- I might go further a step further than that and actually, what your because I've thought about this. I do think that you will see that trend to some level. The -- because the, particularly when you're adding core cutter package, et cetera, we're not -- the -- in cord cutter's package, there is no video product, right, that we will be talking about in these a -- as a revenue-generating unit. But I mean, how important is a revenue-generating unit if it doesn't generate any AOCF, right? And that's sort of the point. So going to probably pay less attention to revenue-generating units and more attention to AOCF and keeping our customers and being able to provide them great service, et cetera than we are x amount of RGUs. Does that answer it?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015

componenttext: That's helpful.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions. Jim, can you give us your opinion of the custom TV bundles Verizon's rolled up, both in terms of their what customers would find appealing basically you guys have done? And also if you think interesting they're doing with their content agre
componenttext: Two questions. Jim, can you give us your opinion of the custom TV bundles Verizon's rolled up, both in terms of their what customers would find appealing basically you guys have done? And also if you think interesting they're doing with their content agreements that you might be able to take advantage of as well down the road? And then for Brian, you mentioned some marketing and employee-related costs benefited the quarter's margin to not sort of read that into the rest of the year. Marketing, I get, it sort of moves up and down but on the employee front, is there anything you'd be specific about? Is there any onetime adjustment? Or it is the higher end more back-end loaded in the year? I just wanted to see if there's any color you can add.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the favorability relative to the prior year period was 2 things. There was part of the switch from cash base, incentive payments to equity-based and there are also adjustments to prior year accruals and the prior year period, so the combination of
componenttext: I think the favorability relative to the prior year period was 2 things. There was part of the switch from cash base, incentive payments to equity-based and there are also adjustments to prior year accruals and the prior year period, so the combination of those 2 things lead to lower employee expenses in the first quarter.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: How do I answer that question. Verizon, I mean, Verizon is known to embellish, use misleading messaging in their marketing to get their phones to ring. I think that's partially how we view these packages. I can tell you that the packages that we're offeri
componenttext: How do I answer that question. Verizon, I mean, Verizon is known to embellish, use misleading messaging in their marketing to get their phones to ring. I think that's partially how we view these packages. I can tell you that the packages that we're offering, right, they provide a lot more flexibility. Whether Verizon -- what their programming, et cetera, don't they seem to think much of their programming agreements. Well, that's really between the programmers and then. But I can tell you that all of the packages that we put out are completely in line with all of our programming agreements and are totally sustainable.

And secondly, the comment around the distribution agreement termination, it sounds like that was a onetime item in the quarter, can you help us size how big that was?

componenttext: The distribution agreement termination was a onetime, it was about $2.8 million.

componenttext: And on the competitive overlap, we see it's at least 50% of our footprint now is covered by Verizon FiOS, and then obviously, satellite as well.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
