componenttextpreview: You know what, the -- I'm not going to give you any numbers, but directionally, I'll tell you that the video business, especially in a competitive marketplace like ours, the -- has margins that are reducing. I think that's -- what -- to what level those a
componenttext: You know what, the -- I'm not going to give you any numbers, but directionally, I'll tell you that the video business, especially in a competitive marketplace like ours, the -- has margins that are reducing. I think that's -- what -- to what level those are depends a lot upon how you do the -- how you do accounting work. So for instance, when a truck rolls to a home, who does that accrue to? Is it the -- I don't think there are any operators out there right now that sits there and divides a truck roll out and says, "Well, he went for a set-top box, so that's just video," right? Or "He went for the router, so that's just data," right? The -- but I do think that directionally you're seeing that the video product begins -- they lose margin and not just amongst the little operators like us but even some of the big operators. The -- and our philosophy with this is essentially that we think that video is akin to the eggs and the milk in a convenience store. You have to have it, but you don't make a lot of money on it. Now connectivity is a whole another basket. It's more like the soda and chips aisle. And the -- if you provide great connectivity because it provides great value to the consumer, you can differentiate yourself and you can charge more, and the margins are good on it. So that's the thought process.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015

componenttext: I guess it's just following with that same theme. So as I think about how you balance the margins of your -- not just your individual products but your overall business, maybe we could return to something we talked about on the last call, which is how do you -- when you see the promotional activity from Verizon FiOS, how do you think about balancing the margins of your service with the need to sustain subscriber growth? How price sensitive are your customers so that you make that price-volume tradeoff in the optimal way?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that what we've been doing is reacting to just that. I think the cord-cutter's package, the et cetera, are reactions to what the consumer wants, that the -- so, I mean, I think it's just basically what I just said before. Kristin, do you wan
componenttext: Well, I think that what we've been doing is reacting to just that. I think the cord-cutter's package, the et cetera, are reactions to what the consumer wants, that the -- so, I mean, I think it's just basically what I just said before. Kristin, do you want to...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we always say we don't comment on Verizon's pricing or activity, but one thing I will comment on is just the level of service that we're providing and the customer response to that. And we do a significant amount of win-backs every year. And
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we always say we don't comment on Verizon's pricing or activity, but one thing I will comment on is just the level of service that we're providing and the customer response to that. And we do a significant amount of win-backs every year. And we really focus on why people are coming back, and it's not just about price. It's -- so we focus on delivering a good product at a great value and not apologizing for our pricing and sticking to our guns on that going down the promotional path. And we're seeing a lot of these initiatives start to really take hold with our customer base.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that's one of the reasons why you've seen the growth in AOCF.
componenttext: I think that's one of the reasons why you've seen the growth in AOCF.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015

componenttext: And so as we look forward, is this about the balance then? Is that kind of what you're kind of optimizing for at this point?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Craig, it's a long-term plan here. And one of the keys for us was to reduce the number of customers that were coming back for constant promotional activity. I think what you've seen over the last year is the subscriber metrics on the video side have decli
componenttext: Craig, it's a long-term plan here. And one of the keys for us was to reduce the number of customers that were coming back for constant promotional activity. I think what you've seen over the last year is the subscriber metrics on the video side have declined. You've seen the -- because you pointed out, the ARPU go up pretty substantially. This is a long game. And I don't think you should necessarily expect to see a continuation of any one trend. You should expect to see us dynamically manage the way that the business operates.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- I might go further, a step further than that. And actually, what you're -- because I've thought about this. I do think that the -- you will see that trend to some level. The -- because the -- particularly when you're adding core-cutter packag
componenttext: Well, the -- I might go further, a step further than that. And actually, what you're -- because I've thought about this. I do think that the -- you will see that trend to some level. The -- because the -- particularly when you're adding core-cutter package, et cetera, we're not -- the -- in a cord-cutter's package there is no video product, right, that we will be talking about in these -- as a revenue-generating unit. But I mean, how important is a revenue-generating unit if it doesn't generate any AOCF, right? The -- and that's sort of the point, that the -- so we're going to probably pay less attention to revenue-generating units and more attention to AOCF and keeping our customers and being able to provide them great service, et cetera, than we are x amount of RGUs. Did that answer it?

componenttext: I think the favorability relative to the prior year period was 2 things. There was part of the switch from cash-based incentive payments to equity based. And there were also adjustments to prior year accruals in the prior year period. So the combination of those 2 things led to lower employee expenses in the first quarter.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gee, how do I answer that question? Verizon-- I mean, Verizon is known to embellish, use misleading messaging in their marketing to get the phones to ring. The -- I think that's partially how we view these packages. I can tell you that the packages that w
componenttext: Gee, how do I answer that question? Verizon-- I mean, Verizon is known to embellish, use misleading messaging in their marketing to get the phones to ring. The -- I think that's partially how we view these packages. I can tell you that the packages that we're offering, right, they provide a lot more flexibility. Whether Verizon -- what their programming agreements are, et cetera, they don't seem to think much of their programming agreements. Well, that's really between the programmers and them, the -- but I can tell you that all of the packages that we put out are completely in line with all of our programming agreements and are totally sustainable.

componenttext: I wanted to follow up a little bit on the video back-and-forth a second ago. Jim, you did an interview recently and didn't say but affirmed that maybe a 10% to 20% decline in video over the next 5 years is the right way to think about it. How do you see that coming from cord cutting versus competition? And then as those video customers go away, what kind of costs can you cut between OpEx and CapEx, aside from the obvious, as the video base declines, to not only grow AOCF but free cash flow?

componenttextpreview: Okay, so my 10% to 20% is totally a wild-ass guess, the -- based upon my 30 years in the business, but the -- we are seeing -- the new generation of consumers are coming in. And I think they use video quite differently than the previous generations. And s
componenttext: Okay, so my 10% to 20% is totally a wild-ass guess, the -- based upon my 30 years in the business, but the -- we are seeing -- the new generation of consumers are coming in. And I think they use video quite differently than the previous generations. And so that's sort of where I derive the number from, the -- I don't have any statistical analysis that will tell me exactly that. It's a seat-of-the-pants guess. What was the other part of your question?

componenttextpreview: CapEx.
componenttext: CapEx.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So to that point, do you see that as being sort of a total, like a disconnect within your footprint from anything? Or is that more competitive?
componenttext: So to that point, do you see that as being sort of a total, like a disconnect within your footprint from anything? Or is that more competitive?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think I just -- look, we don't sit here watching Verizon all the time, right? Nor do we watch DirecTV or DISH, right? What we watch is our customers. We take a look at what their customer experience is. And I think we're -- I think we have great met
componenttext: No. I think I just -- look, we don't sit here watching Verizon all the time, right? Nor do we watch DirecTV or DISH, right? What we watch is our customers. We take a look at what their customer experience is. And I think we're -- I think we have great metrics about that. We're -- I think we're very good at knowing exactly what's going on with our customers, and that's where you see the impetus for a lot of these changes. As far as things like the CapEx goes, I mean, look, the margins are decreasing on the video product, right? The CapEx is not going -- necessarily going down on the video product. You still got boxes in the homes, right? You still got X amount of calls that you're making, et cetera. So it's an unfortunate dynamic in the business because the -- your expenses are either, in the case of, like, programming, going up. In terms of capital on a per-subscriber base, they're not going down, right? The -- and you have -- you're in a competitive marketplace, so there is some ceiling on the level of pricing that you can change -- you can charge. This is squeezing the margin out of the product. And so our -- so I think that our long-term plan is to continue to offer the product, the -- and still try to make it the best product we can, much like the milk and the eggs in the convenience store, right? But we're focusing on the other products that we know actually the consumer differentiates us and that the consumer is paying a lot more attention to than they have in the past, like cord cutters.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm trying to think about the -- sorry, Kristin, go ahead.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I was just going to say, just to add to it, it's a lot about customer behavior and millennials. So it's the cord-nevers that you look at; your kids that watch TV on every screen, except the television, and that are heavily, heavily focused on data and
componenttext: No, I was just going to say, just to add to it, it's a lot about customer behavior and millennials. So it's the cord-nevers that you look at; your kids that watch TV on every screen, except the television, and that are heavily, heavily focused on data and broadband versus traditional TV, so a lot more unicast versus multicast. And when you look at your question about OpEx or CapEx, our infrastructure costs, over time, to deliver broadband are not as aggressive or wouldn't be as aggressive as video product. The ability to develop on more open platforms; the work that Dibble and Wilt are doing on customer capabilities within the homes so that we can troubleshoot from over the phone, as opposed to rolling a truck through the smart routers and the genius routers; and then a broadband product just is much less complex, so the opportunity to reduce not only trouble calls but also phone calls into the call center make that, the broadband products, more attractive on an overall basis for us, although, like Jim says, we'll be selling video our lifetimes and beyond.

componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions on Freewheel. Generally speaking, when you think about the potential customer base and the potential usage of the product, how much of that comes from within your footprint or potential customers for your cable products? And how much of i
componenttext: Just 2 questions on Freewheel. Generally speaking, when you think about the potential customer base and the potential usage of the product, how much of that comes from within your footprint or potential customers for your cable products? And how much of it will either come from outside or the product would be used outside of your footprint? And then along those lines, clearly, investing in WiFi is a priority for you. To the extent that you do have some ambitions for that product to be used across different footprints, how comfortable and confident are you in the WiFi investment by your cable WiFi partners? And do you expect it to be sufficient for that be a growth opportunity?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on Freewheel, as I said earlier, the real purpose for Freewheel is really to improve value perceptions and grow value perceptions for Optimum WiFi. So to that end, we see the bulk of the opportunity within our footprint. That being said, we do see Free
componenttext: So on Freewheel, as I said earlier, the real purpose for Freewheel is really to improve value perceptions and grow value perceptions for Optimum WiFi. So to that end, we see the bulk of the opportunity within our footprint. That being said, we do see Freewheel as an international product. It's a great service. And we get really positive feedback on people taking the phone outside of the U.S., the Caribbean, places like that, so there may be opportunity there. On the overall WiFi investment, I think Jim or Brian can speak to this too, but WiFi is just -- it is the technology for the future. WiFi was built for data. Data consumption increases massively. So we're now seeing, average megabits per session on the plan in the first quarter were almost 24. We're seeing 6 megabits of data being consumed per month for our broadband customers over WiFi. So it's the way of the future. You see cars with WiFi, everywhere you go, airplanes with WiFi. As Jim said, when you went to CES, you didn't see anybody talking about cellular. All the new products, it just assumes a prevalence of WiFi across -- really across the country. And so we're enthusiastic that our cable brethren are continuing to support WiFi. We hope that they will continue do more.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: You've got to remember too that, I mean, Cablevision is 2/3 of the marketplace, right, the -- geographically. Then you take a look at the other -- the most heavily populated area in New York is obviously Manhattan. The -- if you're in Manhattan and you tu
componenttext: You've got to remember too that, I mean, Cablevision is 2/3 of the marketplace, right, the -- geographically. Then you take a look at the other -- the most heavily populated area in New York is obviously Manhattan. The -- if you're in Manhattan and you turn on your phone and you look for WiFi spots, you don't have enough room on your phone. The -- so whether that will be Time Warner or whether that will be somebody else, right, the -- we're pretty confident that WiFi is going to be available ubiquitously across the marketplace. And the fact that we're 2/3 of that marketplace and that we have as robust of a network as we do, I think, bodes well for our products.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: As Jim and Kristin had both indicated, the future for Cablevision is certainly over-the-top, IP-delivered video, which indicates that there's going to be less of a role for the traditional set-top box in the household, just following consumer trends. Cabl
componenttext: As Jim and Kristin had both indicated, the future for Cablevision is certainly over-the-top, IP-delivered video, which indicates that there's going to be less of a role for the traditional set-top box in the household, just following consumer trends. Cablevision is very, very interested in supporting that ecosystem. There are a number of device manufacturers out there now with interesting product offerings, and you'll see something from Cablevision, hopefully, in the not-too-distant future that capitalizes on that without specifically stating whether it's Roku or somebody else. We are committed to taking advantage of what's available in the ecosystem today using open standards and the software that could be placed on that written by us.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Cablevision's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call.Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO; Kristin Dolan, Chief Operating Officer; Brian Sweeney, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Gregg Seibert,
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Cablevision's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call.
Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO; Kristin Dolan, Chief Operating Officer; Brian Sweeney, President and Chief Financial Officer; and Gregg Seibert, Vice Chairman. Jim will start off the call, and then Kristin will provide an operational and product update. Brian will review our financial results, followed by Gregg, who will briefly discuss our capital position and capital allocation strategy prior to moderating our Q&A.
If you do not have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com.
Please note the following. Today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call.
On Page 6 of today's earnings release, we provide a reconciliation of operating income to adjusted operating cash flow, or AOCF.
I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindi. And good morning.Cablevision is off to a solid start in 2015. Consolidated revenue grew more than 2% and AOCF increased nearly 5% compared with the first quarter of 2014. Our capital expenditures were $167 million. Free cash flow was $
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindi. And good morning.
Cablevision is off to a solid start in 2015. Consolidated revenue grew more than 2% and AOCF increased nearly 5% compared with the first quarter of 2014. Our capital expenditures were $167 million. Free cash flow was $49 million. And we declared a $0.15 per share dividend on May 1.
Turning to our strategy. We remain focused on advancing our position as New York's premier connectivity company. Today's digital consumer expects to be connected all the time on all devices wherever they are. And Cablevision's path for continued success is to stay ahead of these changes, and we are determined to do just that.
To achieve this on the product side, we have been advancing connectivity to a broader set of consumers and providing innovative products and service options. We are taking bold steps to connect the customers in new ways. For example, in February, we launched Freewheel. This is our new WiFi-only phone service with unlimited data, talk and text, free from the high costs and data limits imposed by cellular providers. Freewheel leverages the power of our robust WiFi network. It also helps monetize our investment in WiFi.
In March, we announced an agreement to make HBO Now available through the Internet to our high-speed data customers. Cablevision is currently the only cable provider to offer the full suite of HBO products. Just last week, we were the first cable or satellite operator to announce plans to distribute Hulu to our customers. We also recently launched cord-cutter packages that target a new generation of consumers. These offers provide alternatives for those who prefer to access video content through the Internet. Packages are available at different price ranges and all include a digital antenna at no charge for over-the-air TV. This allows customers to bypass the big bundle and still watch broadcast television as well as over-the-top content.
In summary, the company is changing, and these new initiatives are a few examples of our evolution. Going forward, you will see more products and services that focus on flexibility as we reimagine Cablevision and its place in the market.
With that, let me now turn the call over to Kristin Dolan for an operational product -- operational and product overview.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim.First quarter net customer results generally compared favorably with the third and fourth quarters of 2014. We added data customers despite significant competitive discounting and economic pressures in portions of our footprint. Our disci
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim.
First quarter net customer results generally compared favorably with the third and fourth quarters of 2014. We added data customers despite significant competitive discounting and economic pressures in portions of our footprint. Our disciplined approach to pricing, promotional eligibility and customer credit policies has not wavered. We're targeting a stronger base of customers while differentiating the value of Optimum in the marketplace. To this end, during the first quarter, we continued to deliver strong year-over-year growth in revenue per customer.
In addition to the new product offerings that Jim mentioned, let me share some other highlights.
We signed several new clients for our data and analytics service. We're also working with other MSOs to provide combined insights from set-top-box tuning data. We expanded the availability of our 5/1 data service known as Internet Basics. This service, which we initially introduced in Bronx and Newark, is now available across our entire footprint.
On the office end of the data spectrum, Optimum was the first cable company to introduce 1-gigabyte residential service in the tri-state area. The service launched in a new multi-tenant building in Weehawken, New Jersey. This offering showcases the strength and versatility of the Optimum network. We also continued to identify ways to expand the breadth of our WiFi coverage as well as optimize speed and performance.
As we look ahead, our 2015 WiFi growth plan includes deploying access points in high-data-usage areas. Additionally, ongoing investments in our WiFi network will continue to enhance the value of our Freewheel service.
We continue to make service and reliability key differentiators of the Optimum experience. First quarter total customer service phone calls declined by 12% and trouble call truck rolls decreased 21%, each as compared with the prior year period. We're pleased with our progress in the first quarter, and we'll remain highly focused on delivering superior service and enhancing our customer relationships.
With that, let me turn to Brian Sweeney to review our financial results.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kristin.Jim provided an overview of total company results, so now let's review our business segments.During the quarter, we gained 7,000 net high-speed data customers. Customer relationships, video and voice customers declined by 6,000, 28,
componenttext:
Thank you, Kristin.
Jim provided an overview of total company results, so now let's review our business segments.
During the quarter, we gained 7,000 net high-speed data customers. Customer relationships, video and voice customers declined by 6,000, 28,000 and 14,000, respectively. First quarter average monthly revenue per customer increased by more than $7 to $155.34, as compared with the prior year period. This increase is consistent with our pricing strategies and principally reflects recent rate initiatives and our disciplined approach to promotional eligibility and retention policies.
First quarter total cable revenue increased by 2.4%, reflecting the increase in revenue per customer, which was partially offset by fewer customers. As compared with 2014, first quarter cable advertising revenue decreased by 3%, primarily due to lower gaming and banking spending. These declines were offset in part by higher auto and consumer spending, which benefited from addressable advertising campaigns.
Cable AOCF increased 0.8% in the first quarter, as compared with the prior year period. This primarily reflects the impact of revenue growth and lower employee and customer-service-related costs. This was partially offset by fewer customers and higher programming, product development and marketing costs.
Cable capital spending in the first quarter was $134 million, a $12 million decrease from the same period in 2014. This primarily reflects lower CPE spending due to the timing of set-top box and modem purchases, partially offset by continued deployment of our smart routers and further investment in our network to support our new data offering and WiFi expansion.
Lightpath's first quarter revenue increased 5%, and AOCF grew nearly 13%, as compared with the prior year period. These increases reflect revenue growth in Ethernet-based services, partially offset by continuing decline in legacy TDM-based services.
Lightpath has been expanding beyond its traditional voice, data and Internet service offerings to also provide managed services, with a lineup that has grown to include audio and Web conferencing, backup, hosted voice and other services. Additionally, Lightpath has increased its focused on medium-size businesses. Lightpath's growing product portfolio and increasing presence in these markets provides us with an attractive opportunity to grow in the mid-to-large enterprise space.
In our other segment, first quarter revenue was essentially flat, and the AOCF deficit improved by nearly 24%. These results principally reflect higher advertising revenue at News 12, partially offset by lower advertising revenue at Newsday. AOCF also reflects a reduction in expenses at Newsday due to lower operating costs and the termination of a distribution agreement, along with reduced expenses at corporate and certain other businesses. News 12's award-winning hyper-local programming and Newsday's strong editorial presence continue to resonate with our customers and provide a valuable retention tool for the company.
Before I turn it over to Gregg, I would note that our first quarter results were favorably impacted by the timing of several expense items, including marketing and employee-related costs, as well as the timing of capital spending. We've continued to anticipate that 2015 total company AOCF and CapEx, including incremental expenditures for Freewheel and our other new product initiatives, will be substantially similar to our 2014 results. However, we -- as we've said before, this is a dynamic business and we anticipate updating our guidance as the year progresses.
I'll now hand the call over to Gregg Seibert to discuss our capital position and capital allocation strategy.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Brian. Good morning.The company's first quarter consolidated cash position was $884 million, and net debt was $7.8 billion. We had $1.43 billion undrawn and available under the $1.5 billion revolving credit facility at CSC Holdings at t
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Brian. Good morning.
The company's first quarter consolidated cash position was $884 million, and net debt was $7.8 billion. We had $1.43 billion undrawn and available under the $1.5 billion revolving credit facility at CSC Holdings at the end of the first quarter.
At March 31, the company's consolidated net leverage ratio was 4.3x. The CSC Holdings restricted group bank leverage ratio was 2.9x. We did not repurchase shares of Cablevision stock during 2015. We have approximately $450 million of remaining stock repurchase authorization.
Before we open the call for questions, I'd like to touch on the topic of capital allocation, as we are frequently asked how we approach this.
We plan to apply our 2015 free cash flow in a similar manner to 2014. Our current priority is to continue to invest in the business. We will strive to provide the best possible service to our customers, and we are focused on investing in our network, including WiFi. We'll continue to invest in opportunities that will help us realize our ambition of being the premier connectivity company in our market.
The second priority is to ensure that our balance sheet continues to afford us the ability to dynamically manage the business and apply our excess capital. I think it's likely that you'll see a portion of our excess cash applied to our effort to continue to delever. Consistent with this approach, in April, we made a voluntary prepayment of our CSC Holdings term loan B facility in the amount of $200 million. This repayment will result in cash interest savings over the term of the facility.
Number three in our hierarchy is our dividend, which is our primary method of returning capital to shareholders. Finally, as always, we will remain highly disciplined as we evaluate any other potential acquisitions and investment opportunities.
Operator, with that, we'd now like to open the call for questions.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions. The first is your cord-cutter package. Would you consider that more of a proactive strategy, or a reactive strategy, meaning are you seeing up more cord cutters, or are you anticipating there to be more cord cutters? And then secondly,
componenttext: I have 2 questions. The first is your cord-cutter package. Would you consider that more of a proactive strategy, or a reactive strategy, meaning are you seeing up more cord cutters, or are you anticipating there to be more cord cutters? And then secondly, ARPU was pretty strong this quarter. Can you just talk about the rate increases this year versus last year in terms of both timing and magnitude?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, okay. Cord cutters, I wouldn't call it reactive. And I wouldn't -- what was the other one called? Proactive, either. I think that it's just more fully fills out our product offering to our customer base. I think that the -- all of cable companies as
componenttext: Sure, okay. Cord cutters, I wouldn't call it reactive. And I wouldn't -- what was the other one called? Proactive, either. I think that it's just more fully fills out our product offering to our customer base. I think that the -- all of cable companies as well as satellite companies have had issues with having very large bundles that are sometimes difficult for the customer to afford, et cetera, and our ability to offer products underneath that, right, has been limited, primarily limited by the programming contracts. We see the cord-cutters package as a way of filling out that product line and being able to offer levels of service that are less expensive than the big bundle. And the -- I think it also has an aspect where it services the new consumer, the millennial, et cetera, but I think our primary thought is that it's filling out our product lines. Who wants to handle the other one?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right then, your second question. This is Brian. The main drivers of our increased revenue per customer came from a combination of rate increases but also lower proportion of subscribers on promotion. We have a -- we had a number of rate increases on
componenttext: All right then, your second question. This is Brian. The main drivers of our increased revenue per customer came from a combination of rate increases but also lower proportion of subscribers on promotion. We have a -- we had a number of rate increases on January 1 of this year related to cable box fees, an increase in our sports and broadcast TV surcharge, as well as the pass-through of PEG fees to certain of our customers. In addition, RPC benefited from rate increases that were implemented in the second quarter of 2014 and the implementation of a pass-through on voice taxes last summer. So the combination of all of that led to the increase.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm just going to follow up a little bit on the cord-cutter question because the 2 packages that we announced serve 2 different purposes. The first is really for people in economically challenged situations. So these are families that need Internet for th
componenttext: I'm just going to follow up a little bit on the cord-cutter question because the 2 packages that we announced serve 2 different purposes. The first is really for people in economically challenged situations. So these are families that need Internet for their kids to do their homework or things like that. So the digital antenna, plus the 5/1 Internet Basics, plus Freewheel is really for severely economically challenged people, whereas the other cord-cutter package with the ultra 50 is really for people who have either been cord-shavers or cord-nevers, so we're addressing new behavior with that package, but I think it's important. And we always point out that the majority of our customers in an acquisition situation are coming in as Triple Play customers.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on your second question. Free cash flow declined year-over-year, principally due to higher employee incentive payments, which negatively impacted working capital for the quarter, which was only partially offset by the higher AOCF and lower capital spen
componenttext: So on your second question. Free cash flow declined year-over-year, principally due to higher employee incentive payments, which negatively impacted working capital for the quarter, which was only partially offset by the higher AOCF and lower capital spending. A significant portion of this amount was due to adding a discretionary component to our 401(k) benefit plan as an adjustment to freezing our defined benefit plan. And although while we accrue regular contributions for the 401(k) during the calendar year, the discretionary contributions were paid in the first quarter 2015.

componenttext: It's a little early to tell, but I think we've been pretty vocal in our discussion about the fact that current audience measurement is broken and that our success so far in migrating people over from just basic minimal customer data to census-level set-top-box data has really been a positive for us. And we have other MSOs who are securing the same type of data as we are. So we're looking at opportunities to, hopefully, change the commerce in advertising sales to something that's better for the customer and better for the advertiser.

componenttext: 2 questions, 1 on Freewheel and then 1 on the newspaper assets. I guess, first one, Freewheel. And should we expect this will contribute to broadband revenue? And then just on Newsday and News 12, how strategic are these assets? And just can you talk a little bit about some of the ad growth potential going forward?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on Freewheel, we continue to be really enthusiastic about the interest shown. At the end of the first quarter, our weekly visits, our unique weekly visits, increased 16% on average, to our website. The weekly orders are increasing. Our users are
componenttext: Sure. So on Freewheel, we continue to be really enthusiastic about the interest shown. At the end of the first quarter, our weekly visits, our unique weekly visits, increased 16% on average, to our website. The weekly orders are increasing. Our users are making and receiving more than 20 calls a week and sending and receiving more than 70 text messages. And uses per subscriber continues to grow. So we're very, again, continue to be really bullish about WiFi and about Freewheel. On the broadband revenue question, Freewheel, as we've said all along, is really designed to improve customers' understanding and their value perceptions associated with our WiFi network. So Freewheel is really an extension of that. I'm not sure that there's a direct correlation between broadband revenues other than improved retention on broadband through the use of Freewheel.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then on your second question just relative to News 12, and it's how important it is to us. I mean, I think it's a very important tool for our customer base. 70% of our households tune to News 12 on a weekly basis. They've been able to do tremendous gr
componenttext: And then on your second question just relative to News 12, and it's how important it is to us. I mean, I think it's a very important tool for our customer base. 70% of our households tune to News 12 on a weekly basis. They've been able to do tremendous growth in advertising revenue over the last couple of years. And as local advertising and local news advertising, local broadcasters' advertising is going down, News 12 has been incredibly resilient and has actually been able to grow share in those areas.

componenttextpreview: Just a question for Mr. Dolan and maybe Mr. Seibert. I applaud you guys for sort of leaning into this connectivity-centric strategy that you have. It seems to me as a smaller operator that this transition from a video-centric company to a connectivity-cen
componenttext: Just a question for Mr. Dolan and maybe Mr. Seibert. I applaud you guys for sort of leaning into this connectivity-centric strategy that you have. It seems to me as a smaller operator that this transition from a video-centric company to a connectivity-centric company is easier, in a way, because you probably generate lower gross profits on your video product than some of your larger brethren that are in the ecosystem. And in that context, I was just wondering if you would be willing to share in rough terms what your video gross profit margins are today just so we can get a sense of how easy or hard this transition will be.

componenttext: I'm like, no. I think the answer to that is, today, it's still an integrated business. And as a result, it's incumbent upon us to look at the profitability as an integrated business, but potentially, more to come, Jason, as that transition...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: You know what, the -- I'm not going to give you any numbers, but directionally, I'll tell you that the video business, especially in a competitive marketplace like ours, the -- has margins that are reducing. I think that's -- what -- to what level those a
componenttext: You know what, the -- I'm not going to give you any numbers, but directionally, I'll tell you that the video business, especially in a competitive marketplace like ours, the -- has margins that are reducing. I think that's -- what -- to what level those are depends a lot upon how you do the -- how you do accounting work. So for instance, when a truck rolls to a home, who does that accrue to? Is it the -- I don't think there are any operators out there right now that sits there and divides a truck roll out and says, "Well, he went for a set-top box, so that's just video," right? Or "He went for the router, so that's just data," right? The -- but I do think that directionally you're seeing that the video product begins -- they lose margin and not just amongst the little operators like us but even some of the big operators. The -- and our philosophy with this is essentially that we think that video is akin to the eggs and the milk in a convenience store. You have to have it, but you don't make a lot of money on it. Now connectivity is a whole another basket. It's more like the soda and chips aisle. And the -- if you provide great connectivity because it provides great value to the consumer, you can differentiate yourself and you can charge more, and the margins are good on it. So that's the thought process.

componenttext: Well, I think that what we've been doing is reacting to just that. I think the cord-cutters package, the et cetera, are reactions to what the consumer wants, that the -- so, I mean, I think it's just basically what I just said before. Kristin, do you want to...

componenttext: Yes. I mean, we always say we don't comment on Verizon's pricing or activity, but one thing I will comment on is just the level of service that we're providing and the customer response to that. It's -- so we focus on delivering a good product at a great value and not apologizing for our pricing and sticking to our guns on that going down the promotional path. And we're seeing a lot of these initiatives start to really take hold with our customer base.

componenttextpreview: And so as we look forward, is this about the balance then? Should we assume that sort of, right now, it looks like you're getting most of your growth from AOCF -- or from a revenue per account growth but not much growth now in units? Is that kind of what
componenttext: And so as we look forward, is this about the balance then? Should we assume that sort of, right now, it looks like you're getting most of your growth from AOCF -- or from a revenue per account growth but not much growth now in units? Is that kind of what you're kind of optimizing for at this point?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Craig, it's a long-term plan here. And one of the keys for us was to reduce the number of customers that were coming back for constant promotional activity. I think what you've seen over the last year is the subscriber metrics on the video side have decli
componenttext: Craig, it's a long-term plan here. And one of the keys for us was to reduce the number of customers that were coming back for constant promotional activity. I think what you've seen over the last year is the subscriber metrics on the video side have declined. You've seen the -- because you pointed out, the ARPU go up pretty substantially. This is a long game. And I don't think you should necessarily expect to see a continuation of any one trend. You should expect to see us dynamically manage the way that the business operates.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- I might go further, a step further than that. And actually, what you're -- because I've thought about this. I do think that the -- you will see that trend to some level. The -- because the -- particularly when you're adding core-cutter packag
componenttext: Well, the -- I might go further, a step further than that. And actually, what you're -- because I've thought about this. I do think that the -- you will see that trend to some level. The -- because the -- particularly when you're adding core-cutter package, et cetera, we're not -- the -- in a cord-cutters package there is no video product, right, that we will be talking about in these -- as a revenue-generating unit. But I mean, how important is a revenue-generating unit if it doesn't generate any AOCF, right? The -- and that's sort of the point, that the -- so we're going to probably pay less attention to revenue-generating units and more attention to AOCF and keeping our customers and being able to provide them great service, et cetera, than we are x amount of RGUs. Did that answer it?

componenttext: I think the favorability relative to the prior year period was 2 things. There was part of the switch from cash-based incentive payments to equity based. And there were also adjustments to prior year accruals in the prior year period. So the combination of those 2 things led to lower employee expenses in the first quarter.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gee, how do I answer that question? Verizon-- I mean, Verizon is known to embellish, use misleading messaging in their marketing to get the phones to ring. The -- I think that's partially how we view these packages. I can tell you that the packages that w
componenttext: Gee, how do I answer that question? Verizon-- I mean, Verizon is known to embellish, use misleading messaging in their marketing to get the phones to ring. The -- I think that's partially how we view these packages. I can tell you that the packages that we're offering, right, they provide a lot more flexibility. Whether Verizon -- what their programming agreements are, et cetera, they don't seem to think much of their programming agreements. Well, that's really between the programmers and them, the -- but I can tell you that all of the packages that we put out are completely in line with all of our programming agreements and are totally sustainable.

componenttext: I wanted to follow up a little bit on the video back-and-forth a second ago. How do you see that coming from cord cutting versus competition? And then as those video customers go away, what kind of costs can you cut between OpEx and CapEx, aside from the obvious, as the video base declines, to not only grow AOCF but free cash flow?

componenttext: Okay, so my 10% to 20% is totally a wild-ass guess, the -- based upon my 30 years in the business, but the -- we are seeing -- the new generation of consumers are coming in. And I think they use video quite differently than the previous generations. And so that's sort of where I derive the number from, the -- I don't have any statistical analysis that will tell me exactly that. It's a seat-of-the-pants guess. What was the other part of your question?

componenttext: So to that point, do you see that as being sort of a total, like a disconnect within your footprint from anything? Or is that more competitive?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think I just -- look, we don't sit here watching Verizon all the time, right? Nor do we watch DirecTV or DISH, right? What we watch is our customers. We take a look at what their customer experience is. And I think we're -- I think we have great met
componenttext: No. I think I just -- look, we don't sit here watching Verizon all the time, right? Nor do we watch DirecTV or DISH, right? What we watch is our customers. We take a look at what their customer experience is. And I think we're -- I think we have great metrics about that. We're -- I think we're very good at knowing exactly what's going on with our customers, and that's where you see the impetus for a lot of these changes. As far as things like the CapEx goes, I mean, look, the margins are decreasing on the video product, right? The CapEx is not going -- necessarily going down on the video product. You still got boxes in the homes, right? You still got X amount of calls that you're making, et cetera. So it's an unfortunate dynamic in the business because the -- your expenses are either, in the case of, like, programming, going up. In terms of capital on a per-subscriber base, they're not going down, right? The -- and you have -- you're in a competitive marketplace, so there is some ceiling on the level of pricing that you can change -- you can charge. This is squeezing the margin out of the product. And so our -- so I think that our long-term plan is to continue to offer the product, the -- and still try to make it the best product we can, much like the milk and the eggs in the convenience store, right? But we're focusing on the other products that we know actually the consumer differentiates us and that the consumer is paying a lot more attention to than they have in the past, like cord cutters.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I was just going to say, just to add to it, it's a lot about customer behavior and millennials. So it's the cord-nevers that you look at; your kids that watch TV on every screen, except the television, and that are heavily, heavily focused on data and
componenttext: No, I was just going to say, just to add to it, it's a lot about customer behavior and millennials. So it's the cord-nevers that you look at; your kids that watch TV on every screen, except the television, and that are heavily, heavily focused on data and broadband versus traditional TV, so a lot more unicast versus multicast. And when you look at your question about OpEx or CapEx, our infrastructure costs, over time, to deliver broadband are not as aggressive or wouldn't be as aggressive as video product. The ability to develop on more open platforms; the work that Dibble and Wilt are doing on customer capabilities within the homes so that we can troubleshoot from over the phone, as opposed to rolling a truck through the smart routers and the genius routers; and then a broadband product just is much less complex, so the opportunity to reduce not only trouble calls but also phone calls into the call center make that, the broadband products, more attractive on an overall basis for us, although, like Jim says, we'll be selling video our lifetimes and beyond.

componenttext: Just 2 questions on Freewheel. Generally speaking, when you think about the potential customer base and the potential usage of the product, how much of that comes from within your footprint or potential customers for your cable products? And how much of it will either come from outside or the product would be used outside of your footprint? And then along those lines, clearly, investing in WiFi is a priority for you. To the extent that you do have some ambitions for that product to be used across different footprints, how comfortable and confident are you in the WiFi investment by your cable WiFi partners? And do you expect it to be sufficient for that be a growth opportunity?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on Freewheel, as I said earlier, the real purpose for Freewheel is really to improve value perceptions and grow value perceptions for Optimum WiFi. So to that end, we see the bulk of the opportunity within our footprint. That being said, we do see Free
componenttext: So on Freewheel, as I said earlier, the real purpose for Freewheel is really to improve value perceptions and grow value perceptions for Optimum WiFi. So to that end, we see the bulk of the opportunity within our footprint. That being said, we do see Freewheel as an international product. It's a great service. And we get really positive feedback on people taking the phone outside of the U.S., the Caribbean, places like that, so there may be opportunity there. On the overall WiFi investment, I think Jim or Brian can speak to this too, but WiFi is just -- it is the technology for the future. WiFi was built for data. Data consumption increases massively. So we're now seeing, average megabits per session on the plan in the first quarter were almost 24. We're seeing 6 megabits of data being consumed per month for our broadband customers over WiFi. So it's the way of the future. You see cars with WiFi, everywhere you go, airplanes with WiFi. As Jim said, when you went to CES, you didn't see anybody talking about cellular. All the new products, it just assumes a prevalence of WiFi across -- really across the country. And so we're enthusiastic that our cable brethren are continuing to support WiFi. We hope that they will continue do more.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: You've got to remember too that, I mean, Cablevision is 2/3 of the marketplace, right, the -- geographically. Then you take a look at the other -- the most heavily populated area in New York is obviously Manhattan. The -- if you're in Manhattan and you tu
componenttext: You've got to remember too that, I mean, Cablevision is 2/3 of the marketplace, right, the -- geographically. Then you take a look at the other -- the most heavily populated area in New York is obviously Manhattan. The -- if you're in Manhattan and you turn on your phone and you look for WiFi spots, you don't have enough room on your phone. The -- so whether that will be Time Warner or whether that will be somebody else, right, the -- we're pretty confident that WiFi is going to be available ubiquitously across the marketplace. And the fact that we're 2/3 of that marketplace and that we have as robust of a network as we do, I think, bodes well for our products.

componenttext: As Jim and Kristin had both indicated, the future for Cablevision is certainly over-the-top, IP-delivered video, which indicates that there's going to be less of a role for the traditional set-top box in the household, just following consumer trends. Cablevision is very, very interested in supporting that ecosystem. There are a number of device manufacturers out there now with interesting product offerings, and you'll see something from Cablevision, hopefully, in the not-too-distant future that capitalizes on that without specifically stating whether it's Roku or somebody else. We are committed to taking advantage of what's available in the ecosystem today using open standards and the software that could be placed on that written by us.
