headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Christie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Cablevision Systems Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call o
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Christie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Cablevision Systems Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Cindi Buckwalter, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Cablevision's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO; Kristin Dolan, Chief Operating Officer; and Brian Sweeney, President and Chief Financial Officer. Jim will start
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Cablevision's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO; Kristin Dolan, Chief Operating Officer; and Brian Sweeney, President and Chief Financial Officer. Jim will start off the call, and then Kristine will provide an operational and product update. Brian will conclude with a review with our financial results. Gregg Seibert, our Vice Chairman, will be available for Q&A. If you do not have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com.
Please note the following. Today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call.
On Page 6 of today's earnings release, we provide a reconciliation of operating income to adjusted operating cash flow or AOCF. 
I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindi, and good morning. Our second quarter financial results met our expectations. Consolidated revenue grew 2% and AOCF decreased 3% compared to the prior year period. Year-to-date, AOCF is in line with our 2015 outlook. Our capital expenditu
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindi, and good morning. Our second quarter financial results met our expectations. Consolidated revenue grew 2% and AOCF decreased 3% compared to the prior year period. Year-to-date, AOCF is in line with our 2015 outlook. Our capital expenditures during the quarter were $215 million. Free cash flow was $158 million. And we continued to return capital to shareholders with a dividend of $0.15 per share declared in August 6.  Overall, we're satisfied with our results.
Turning to operations. The metric we are most enthusiastic about is customer relationships. We gained 5,000 total customers, marking the first quarter of growth in more than 2 years. New technologies and consumer behaviors continue to challenge the big bundle. It's clear that this dynamic with the customer is changing, which is why today, the overall customer relationship number is more relevant than individual product metrics.
As a leading service provider in the most sophisticated markets in the country, we saw these trends coming. And that is why earlier this year, we were the first and only provider to introduce cord-cutter packages. We recognized that the traditional video bundle does not work for all consumers, so we are offering flexibility, choice and new products to meet their evolving connectivity needs.
We have been positioning the company to address this changing market for several years. Beginning in 2012, Cablevision embarked on a new strategic path to become the premier connectivity company in the New York market. We made substantial investments in technology, tools and people to provide the best experience to our customers. Most importantly, we focused on the reliability and performance of our networks. As a result, we more than doubled our broadband capacity, optimized the density and quality of our WiFi experience, enabled the more innovative product set with flexible service offerings and improved our ability to monitor network performance and address issues proactively.
These investments have also made our operations more efficient. We have reduced trouble call truck rolls in half and customer calls by nearly 30% compared to the 2012 levels. This has led to lower costs and improved customer satisfaction. At the same time, we chose to compete on value, not solely on price, by taking a more disciplined approach to promotional eligibility and customer credit policies. The changes to the way we do business has resulted in a stronger base of customers who are more satisfied. That has helped decreased our voluntary competitive churn to a nearly 6-year low in the second quarter.
On the product side, we continue to innovate with our over-the-top offerings and witnessed speedy increase in our core data service. We have also changed the Cablevision employee experience by investing in the development of our people. As a result, we have created a performance-based culture throughout all levels of the company.
I'm going to close my portion of the call with some remarks about Verizon. Our first direct competition with them was in the landline phone business. From a standing start, we took more than 2 million of their residential phone customers, and Cablevision became the dominant phone provider in our market. Verizon has invested billions of dollars in FiOS in the tri-state area. Today, Cablevision serves more than 3.1 million customers, down from 3.3 million customers at our peak in 2008. This is despite FiOS' heavily bundled overbuild and deeply discounted pricing as well as the economy and other competitive forces. The impact of FiOS on Cablevision has been minimal. To the extent that we have lost customers to FiOS, we believe that they are usually promotional shoppers in search of the lowest price services. FiOS has almost certainly performed better against the satellite companies than it has against Cablevision. We believe that the Verizon FiOS is an unprofitable business today, and we doubt that they will ever be profitable.
Our strategic plan and investments during the past 3 years have helped to transform Cablevision. Our focus on price discipline has allowed us to grow revenue per customer. Our voluntary churn is down, and we have retained our highest-value customers. In addition today, Cablevision operates the nation's most robust WiFi network, while Verizon has no public WiFi. 
Cablevision has changed its culture. We no longer think like a monopoly, and instead, we are strategic, effective and competitive. Our approach to connectivity as a new frontier is gaining traction. This is reflected by our growth in customer relationships this quarter.
The Verizon FiOS effect, if there was ever -- if there ever was one, in our opinion, is over. Our business is healthy, and I'm confident that we'll get even stronger as we move forward.
With that, let me turn the call over to Kristin Dolan for an operational and product update.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. The actions we've taken over the last 3 years to reimagine Cablevision have resulted in a faster, more reliable network that excelled at delivering new and sophisticated products and services. on June's update the improvements we've made h
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. The actions we've taken over the last 3 years to reimagine Cablevision have resulted in a faster, more reliable network that excelled at delivering new and sophisticated products and services. on June's update the improvements we've made have enhanced the customer experience and have reduced costly service-related transactions.  
For example, through proactive monitoring of the network, we're able to identify risk points and intervene before the customer is affected. We triage every trouble call before we roll a truck, identifying the source of the issue and eliminating unnecessary truck rolls. And we've armed our technicians with advanced tools that enable faster repair times and facilitate the goal of first call resolution, solving the problem in our first visit to the home. These initiatives are resonating with our customers and leading to superior service experience. Accordingly, second quarter trouble call truck rolls decreased 19% as compared with the prior year period. We also experienced a 13% reduction in calls to customer service over the same period.
We implemented a voice of the customer dashboard earlier this year to capture real-time customer feedback and measure Net Promoter Score, a tool widely used by many leading companies to obtain feedback from customers. Responses to this new approach has been strong. We'll harness the insights from these surveys to further improve customer satisfaction and operational efficiencies.
We also continue to innovate in the product area. In the second quarter, we introduced our cord-cutter packages to serve a new generation that prefers connection to video content through the Internet. The cord cutter offerings provide access to different levels of Internet service at varying price points. They all include a digital antenna at no charge for over the year TV. This allows customers to bypass the big bundle and still watch broadcast television as well as over-the-top content. These packages are attracting new interest. They have also allowed us to engage differently with consumers who are looking for options to fit their individual connectivity needs and budgets.
Changes in our acquisition and retention practices helped improve customer activities during the quarter, with fewer disconnects and an overall net gain of 5,000 total customers as Jim mentioned. We also experienced the largest quarterly data net additions since the first quarter of 2015.
Turning to our network. Our investments in this area have transformed our high-speed data service into the premier broadband offerings in the New York marketplace.  Let me share a few specifics. 
During the last 2 years, average daily usage per customer has increased by 190%. Today, 90% of customer relationships include broadband service. In addition, nearly half of Optimum Online customers currently subscribe to premium speed tiers, and more than half of data customers use 50 gigabits or more per month.
Now let's turn to WiFi. Over the last 3 years, WiFi access and usage has grown exponentially across all metrics. For example, Optimum WiFi access points have increased from less than 50,000 to more than 1.3 million. We rolled out 1 million in home smart routers at no incremental cost to our customers. And monthly WiFi data usage per customer increased from less than 1 gigabyte to more than 6 gigabytes over the same 3-year period. We will continue to make investments in our WiFi networks through the deployment of additional WiFi access points in high-data-usage areas.
Moving on. Other highlights for the quarter include offering HBO Now and Hulu as an over-the-top offerings to our broadband customers, entering into a long-term agreement with ESPN Disney for our data and analytics service, and continuing to work with other MSOs to provide combined insights for set-top box tuning data.
We're pleased with the progress in the first half of 2015, and we'll remain focused on delivering superior service and enhancing our customer relationships.
With that, let me turn to Brian Sweeney to review our financial results.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kristin, and good morning. During the quarter, total customers increased by 5,000 and high-speed data customers increased by 14,000. Video and voice customers declined by 16,000 and 7,000 respectively. We're seeing more favorable customer trend
componenttext:
Thank you, Kristin, and good morning. During the quarter, total customers increased by 5,000 and high-speed data customers increased by 14,000. Video and voice customers declined by 16,000 and 7,000 respectively. We're seeing more favorable customer trends over the last few quarters as a direct result of the numerous actions taken to increase broadband capacity, improve network reliability and enhance customer service. We have also built a stronger customer base with reduced churn and lower voluntary disconnects. Average monthly revenue per customer in the second quarter increased by nearly $6 to $158.52 as compared with the prior year period. This performance was principally driven by recent initiatives and our disciplined approach to promotional eligibility and retention policies as well as increased transactional revenue from a pay-per-view event during the quarter.
Second quarter total cable revenue increased by 1.8%, reflecting the increase in revenue per customer, which was partially offset by fewer customers compared to the prior year period and lower advertising.
Cable AOCF decreased 3.4% in the second quarter as compared to the prior year period. This primarily reflects higher programming costs, legal fees and product development and marketing costs, partially offset by the impact of revenue growth and lower customer service-related costs. 
I want to provide a little more color on our advertising revenue. As compared with 2014, second quarter cable advertising revenue decreased by 11% primarily due to reduced spending with fewer candidate campaigns this year, along with lower spending in the financial, gaming and cable programming sectors. The declines in certain categories of our advertising revenue were offset in part by higher local recreational and consumer spending. Notably, the number of addressable advertising campaigns doubled compared to the prior year period, and we are seeing pronounced interest in impression-based sales.
Moving on to CapEx. Cable capital spending in the second quarter was $186 million, a $21 million decrease from same period in 2014. This primarily reflects a lower year-over-year spending on set-top box and modem purchases as well as the timing of certain video-related projects. These declines were partially offset by higher project spending to support broadband and WiFi expansion. We expect increased CapEx spending in the back half of 2015 as we continue to invest in the evolution of our product offerings and ensure a quality service experience.
Moving on to our other business segments. Lightpath second quarter revenue increased 3% and AOCF grew nearly 12% as compared to the prior year period. The revenue increase reflects growth in Ethernet-based services, partially offset by the continuing decline in legacy TDM-based services. AOCF growth was also driven by lower expenses.
In our other segment, second quarter revenue decreased 3.7% and the AOCF deficit increased by 4%. The decrease in revenue was primarily due to lower advertising revenue at Newsday, partially offset by higher advertising revenue at News 12. The decline in AOCF reflects lower overall net revenues and higher employee-related costs at corporate, partially offset by a reduction in operating expenses at Newsday.
Now turning to the company financial position. The company's second quarter consolidated cash position was $797 million, and net debt was $7.7 billion. We had $1.43 billion of undrawn and available under the $1.5 billion revolving credit facility at CSC Holdings as of the end of the second quarter.  As previously mentioned on our May earnings call, during the second quarter, we made a voluntary repayment of our CSC Holdings term loan B facility in the amount of $200 million. This repayment will result in cash interest savings over the term of the facility. 
We remain focused on identifying opportunities to reduce leverage, strengthen our balance sheet and improve our liquidity position.  At June 30, the company's consolidated net leverage ratio was 4.1x. The CSC Holdings restricted group bank leverage ratio was 2.7x. 
We have not repurchased shares of Cablevision stock during 2015, and we have approximately $450 million of remaining stock repurchase authorization.
We continue to anticipate that 2015 total company AOCF and CapEx, including incremental expenditures for product initiatives, will be substantially similar to our 2014 results.
Before we move to Q&A, we know the topic of M&A continues to be in all of your minds, but this call is to discuss our second quarter results. We will not be entertaining questions today relating to industry consolidation.
Operator, we would now like to open the call for questions.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question comes from Jessica Cohen of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question comes from Jessica Cohen of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess two questions. The first one, I just wanted -- I hope to follow up on what Kristin was talking about on the video bundle. Kristin, can you give any color on -- you guys offer more choice in different packages. This is obviously the -- I mean, give
componenttext: I guess two questions. The first one, I just wanted -- I hope to follow up on what Kristin was talking about on the video bundle. Kristin, can you give any color on -- you guys offer more choice in different packages. This is obviously the -- I mean, given what's happened in the last few days and the scare's that the bundles are falling apart. In your experience, can you tell us, like who's taking the nontraditional packages, the skinny packages? How quickly are you seeing customers to pick, go down and move down from the big video packages, traditional video packages to the skinny bundles?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me start with the skinny bundle. Let me talk that differently, sorry. The cord-cutting packages are definitely making the phone ring, but the bulk of people are still buying 3 products. So -- And the cord-cutter packages are really going to new acq
componenttext: So let me start with the skinny bundle. Let me talk that differently, sorry. The cord-cutting packages are definitely making the phone ring, but the bulk of people are still buying 3 products. So -- And the cord-cutter packages are really going to new acquisitions, the customers that we wouldn't normally get. So we're not seeing a migration of existing products moving to cord cutters or to skinnier bundles. We're really, I think, attracting new customers and also making the phone ring with price point associated, and then upselling the bulk of those customers to an additional 3-product bundle.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess just a follow-up, do you guys have a point of view on how quickly the traditional bundle will -- how much -- in terms of -- I'm sorry...
componenttext: So I guess just a follow-up, do you guys have a point of view on how quickly the traditional bundle will -- how much -- in terms of -- I'm sorry...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. Jessica, I don't think the sky is falling quite yet. And I think that there's not enough programming weight yet in the Internet right, and then in the over-the-top services that are out there to really entice a mainstream video customer that th
componenttext: Yes, I do. Jessica, I don't think the sky is falling quite yet. And I think that there's not enough programming weight yet in the Internet right, and then in the over-the-top services that are out there to really entice a mainstream video customer that the innovators, et cetera, some of the -- I don't call it fringe, but some of the not mainstream video watchers start to adopt the over-the-top. But I do think eventually though that there will be enough of -- enough programming for over-the-top to be competitive with the traditional video bundle. But this is not something that I think is going to happen over a very short period of time. The consumers have become very, very comfortable with the amount of choice that cable offers. And if you want to have a very, very wide variety of choice that the bundle actually is somehow still efficient, that the -- it's essentially buying the entire magazine stand even though you're going to -- because you want the choice of every magazine in there, but you'll only look at maybe several a day or whatever. But you don't want to give up your access to the whole magazine stand. The consumers have gotten very used to that, but it's pricey. And so as you continue to see that price push up, which inevitably you will because the programmers are raising their rates on obviously on a regular basis, particularly the broadcasters, who see it as a bit of a pot of gold. That will drive the people who are more price-sensitive into alternatives. And Internet is obviously, ip over-the-top is starting to become a real alternative. And then with -- that is why we introduced the cord-cutter package with digital antenna. Because the digital antenna actually takes the programming bundle up to the point where it is somewhat competitive with traditional bundle and at a price that's affordable. So I think it's right for you to watch what happens with that, but I don't think that we're going to see a landslide of consumers move from one to the other. And my own prediction is that it will be at least 5 years for 10% of the market to move and 10 years for 30% of the market to move. How's that for an answer?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. I just have one different question, which is when would you reconsider reinstating the share repurchase program?
componenttext: That's great. I just have one different question, which is when would you reconsider reinstating the share repurchase program?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jessica, we view the dividend as a primary form of return of capital to our shareholders. The original repurchase programs were put in place at a time when we had transactions that, for one reason or another, provided additional liquidity, such as the spi
componenttext: Jessica, we view the dividend as a primary form of return of capital to our shareholders. The original repurchase programs were put in place at a time when we had transactions that, for one reason or another, provided additional liquidity, such as the spin-off of AMC, which provided a lot of liquidity for share repurchase. But I think now the board is quite comfortable with the dividend being the primary return of capital. I'm not going to rule it out, but we'd look at it be on an opportunistic basis at this point in time. We've been reinvesting in the business, think the dividend and deleveraging. Those are the primary uses of capital.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question comes from Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have one for Jim and then a quick one for Brian. Jim, on new repositioned the company as a connectivity company as you said. And the subscriber number are showing that's been quite successful. Interestingly, Verizon seems to be growing in the opposite d
componenttext: I have one for Jim and then a quick one for Brian. Jim, on new repositioned the company as a connectivity company as you said. And the subscriber number are showing that's been quite successful. Interestingly, Verizon seems to be growing in the opposite directions with their Go 90 product where they're actually going into the programming business. So when you guys look at your products suite and all of the innovation you've got there, which again seems to be resonating nicely, do you ever think about getting into mobile programming package business? Or do you think that's just the wrong strategy? And then Brian, I'm just wondering if you can talk about the pay-per-view impact in the quarter for us, given that was an unusually unpopular fight, so we can understand that.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm actually going to pass that one over to Kristin because that's really her sweet spot area. So go ahead now.
componenttext: I'm actually going to pass that one over to Kristin because that's really her sweet spot area. So go ahead now.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, fine what's going to to go first. But yes, we've had programming in the past that from we understand the business really well. I think it's a crowded marketplace right now where I think they have seen successes in things like having Major League Base
componenttext: Yes, fine what's going to to go first. But yes, we've had programming in the past that from we understand the business really well. I think it's a crowded marketplace right now where I think they have seen successes in things like having Major League Baseball available on an exclusive basis to mobile customers. It's a really expensive proposition. I don't think necessarily that it's additive to our overall strategy. I don't think it generates incremental revenue particularly. And our focus is really delivering the product, having the best service and the best pipeline to deliver whatever anybody wants to buy from us or from over-the-top providers. So I don't see the mobile content strategy as being one that would be critical to our overall approach.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that the mobile carriers are trying to differentiate themselves, that they -- because they don't have much to differentiate themselves. So I mean, that's why I think -- that's why there -- the best thing in that kind of thing, but I think it's rea
componenttext: I think that the mobile carriers are trying to differentiate themselves, that they -- because they don't have much to differentiate themselves. So I mean, that's why I think -- that's why there -- the best thing in that kind of thing, but I think it's really all about mobile revenue, right? It's not about a new product set, it's about winning the battle against the competitor for them.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the pay-per-view question, that fight was actually the most successful pay-per-view event that we ever had, so it did have a meaningful contribution on revenue. I think on a AOCF basis, it contributed about $5 million of AOCF during the quarter. We're
componenttext: On the pay-per-view question, that fight was actually the most successful pay-per-view event that we ever had, so it did have a meaningful contribution on revenue. I think on a AOCF basis, it contributed about $5 million of AOCF during the quarter. We're also quite pleased with all the enhancements that we put in the network that we didn't have any customer service issues in dealing with the huge interest that was in that fight.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Marci Ryvicker of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Marci Ryvicker of Wells Fargo.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have two. Jim, when you talked about Verizon at the beginning, you often get asked in these calls if there's any change in competition, and normally, the answer is no. So when you come out with such strong commentary, is it that competition is actually
componenttext: I have two. Jim, when you talked about Verizon at the beginning, you often get asked in these calls if there's any change in competition, and normally, the answer is no. So when you come out with such strong commentary, is it that competition is actually getting easier? I mean, FiOS is the best numbers? Or is Cablevision just that much stronger? That's the first question. And then the second question, do you envision as video subs go down, whatever it is, 10% or 30%, that you can make all that up in high-speed data pricing in tiers? Or is it your vision that at some point, you're in a -- or the industry's in a secular decline?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. The first one is about -- I'm getting old, I'm sorry. Now what was the first question about?
componenttext: Okay. The first one is about -- I'm getting old, I'm sorry. Now what was the first question about?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Verizon.
componenttext: Verizon.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: The Verizon.
componenttext: The Verizon.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. I turned 60 this year, my excuse. I really see Cablevision having, over the last 3 years, focused very heavily on our culture and our attitude here about how we do business. The -- And we saw ourselves back 3 or 4 years ago as really bein
componenttext: Okay, thank you. I turned 60 this year, my excuse. I really see Cablevision having, over the last 3 years, focused very heavily on our culture and our attitude here about how we do business. The -- And we saw ourselves back 3 or 4 years ago as really being a sort of operating in the form of a classic cable company, which is really a monopoly. I know that some in the industry don't like to call themselves that, but if you're the only provider, that sort of makes you the monopoly. We're clearly not the only provider in our marketplace, and it was time for us to recognize that. But just recognizing it didn't -- doesn't change overnight. It's taken us a good 3.5 years to get ourselves in a position where we are truly effective competitors and we address the realities of the marketplace. What I said today is a reflection of Cablevision's strength, and the numbers are up quite nicely, and I expect that we can get only stronger as a competitor. So that's really the basis of my comments on that. Other than that, I think we do find it at least a little annoying over here that Verizon continues to tag its FiOS product as being successful when we know very well that, that is definitely not the case, at least in our footprint. And they refuse to break out their numbers, so they just sit there and beat their chests saying "Yes, I am. Yes, I am," and everything that we see says, no, they aren't. So there's a little bit of in there. The second part of your question was on the bundle and erosion of the bundle, and the -- I do see our ability actually to make up from loss of video customers. But you should understand that video customers actually are not the most valuable customers. By far and away, data customers are the most valuable customers at a ratio here of close to 7:1 that they -- and so as we continue to improve our ability to offer connectivity to our customers, I do expect that our suite of offerings of them will increase, that there'll be more revenue opportunities in there for specialized use as well as expanded use. And use by the way, continues to grow exponential -- exponentially. And so the outlook for data is very strong. And with video, their margins continue to decrease. And our intention is to ultimately be able to offer to our customers not only our video package, but other videos packages versus an IP connection and further reduce our costs, but improve the profitability of the company that way.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Craig Moffett of Craig Moffett Nathanson.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Craig Moffett of Craig Moffett Nathanson.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jimmy, I wonder if you can continue just with the same thing for a second. As someone who is an owner of assets in the physical distribution business, but also AMC's content and MSG Sports, how do you think about where that is going to be created in the v
componenttext: Jimmy, I wonder if you can continue just with the same thing for a second. As someone who is an owner of assets in the physical distribution business, but also AMC's content and MSG Sports, how do you think about where that is going to be created in the value chain within the assets that you own? And how is that evolving as you start to think about skinny bundles on your side of the distribution business?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Craig, let me ask you a favor please, right. Only my mother calls the Jimmy. So I appreciate it if you call me Jim. As far as the value chain, today is a call about Cablevision. I will be doing a call about Madison Square Garden I think later in the month
componenttext: Craig, let me ask you a favor please, right. Only my mother calls the Jimmy. So I appreciate it if you call me Jim. As far as the value chain, today is a call about Cablevision. I will be doing a call about Madison Square Garden I think later in the month. But I think the value equation here is just what I said in my last answer. I mean, that the -- it's in the data services, it's in the -- we have gone over the last 10 years from a point where our customers value video as the -- that was the most important product and that was the most decisive product in terms of choosing providers that the -- Now it's data, and its connectivity. And it's not just connectivity to the home, but it's wireless connectivity, the ability to offer products and services in both areas at both at home and mobile-ly [ph] is where we're focusing. And along with that, I think that we will be able to distinguish ourselves, to separate ourselves from our competitors and be able to charge a premium for services that only we provide.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can I ask a follow-up question about your 7:1 ratio that you said for the value of the customers? It -- What's the solution to that? Is it to say we're going to be very selective for which customers with video we take? Or is it to say we're going to repri
componenttext: Can I ask a follow-up question about your 7:1 ratio that you said for the value of the customers? It -- What's the solution to that? Is it to say we're going to be very selective for which customers with video we take? Or is it to say we're going to reprice video in order to ensure that for the customers that we have that it's profitable? Or is it simply to shift away from video and pare back expenses, including potentially dropping some programming in order to sort of rightsize the cost side of the video equation?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know about the programming part, Craig, but video is turning into, if it isn't already, the milk, eggs and bread of the convenience store. You have to have them, right? The customer wants them, right? But it's not, as I said before, it's not the m
componenttext: I don't know about the programming part, Craig, but video is turning into, if it isn't already, the milk, eggs and bread of the convenience store. You have to have them, right? The customer wants them, right? But it's not, as I said before, it's not the most important product, right? That data is the most important product. But if you just offered data alone, right, that the other providers offer video, you wouldn't capture the customer because you got to be -- have to sell milk, bread and eggs along with everything else of the back of the store. We have far and away have the best back of the store. And the milk, bread and eggs, you just need to stay fresh, and they are equal to what's available out there until what most customers want. So that means that you don't have to carry every service. You don't have to be on the cutting edge of every technology that has to do with video because customers don't necessarily always want those. You can keep your costs down as you can try and maintain some level of margin, right. But over the long run, it's the back of the store that's going to make you profitable.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ben Swinburne of Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ben Swinburne of Macquarie.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to focus a little bit more on the cord-cutting packages. I know it's early days, but are there any takeaway you can talk to for Hulu and HBO? And I think Kristin, you mentioned in your earlier comments that most customers are still taking the Tri
componenttext: I wanted to focus a little bit more on the cord-cutting packages. I know it's early days, but are there any takeaway you can talk to for Hulu and HBO? And I think Kristin, you mentioned in your earlier comments that most customers are still taking the Triple Play package. So are these cord-cutting packages just drumming up call center volumes? Or are people actually taking them? And if they are, is it because of economic or generational shifts in doing?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just to repeat, Amy, what I said before, you are correct. Yes, they do make the phone ring. The bulk of people are being upsold into triple product, triple-product bundles. We do see, like I said, acquisitions. So millennials are definitely interested
componenttext: So just to repeat, Amy, what I said before, you are correct. Yes, they do make the phone ring. The bulk of people are being upsold into triple product, triple-product bundles. We do see, like I said, acquisitions. So millennials are definitely interested in cord-cutting packages and are actually happy with the lower and cord-cutting package that will allow people in more financially conservative situation so to have access to Internet and to broadcast television. But to kind of go back a little bit to Craig's question about expense, we are able to see too that the broadband-only customers require a much lower level of service from us. They call us less, and our need to roll trucks against them is less. So combining those 2 things, we're very positive on the opportunity to sell this type of package. But it's really it's fringe. It's people that we haven't had before, and again the attractiveness of it makes the phone ring. But against the bread-and-eggs model, when people do call and we say, "Okay, in order to get that price, this is the programming service you'll get." And when they see that they're missing a lot of the core fundamental cable TV content, they much prefer to go to a more traditional television package.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then you mentioned the CapEx is going to bump up in the second half. Can you speak to the magnitude of the bump up? And where are the bigger buckets of CapEx spend at this point? Looks like CPE and scalable infrastructure actually went down in
componenttext: Great. And then you mentioned the CapEx is going to bump up in the second half. Can you speak to the magnitude of the bump up? And where are the bigger buckets of CapEx spend at this point? Looks like CPE and scalable infrastructure actually went down in the quarter. So I'm wondering what you're actually investing in?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just as a comment, our guidance for the year is that CapEx spending is actually potentially similar to what it was last year. So I think what you've seen in terms of lower CapEx this quarter year-to-date is more just timing of projects, timing of CPE p
componenttext: So just as a comment, our guidance for the year is that CapEx spending is actually potentially similar to what it was last year. So I think what you've seen in terms of lower CapEx this quarter year-to-date is more just timing of projects, timing of CPE purchases. And so we still expect for total CapEx spending to be comparable to last year. I think relative to why we're lower relative to last year, as examples, we have higher investment in scalable infrastructure last year as we are doing investments in our cloud DVR services where we've had lower of that this year. Relative to the first quarter, why it's being up, basically, it's timing of set-top box purchases and just higher spending on all our bandwidth augmentation to support the higher speeds that we put in place.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michael Morris of Guggenheim Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Morris of Guggenheim Partners.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question is about how you think about the over-the-top offerings from companies that you pay for the same content. So an example, not specific to this, but an example would be CBS All Access where their over-the-top product looks extremely similar to w
componenttext: My question is about how you think about the over-the-top offerings from companies that you pay for the same content. So an example, not specific to this, but an example would be CBS All Access where their over-the-top product looks extremely similar to what you pay retransmission fees for. So I guess generally speaking for these types of offerings, do your agreements allow for this? I know you don't speak to specific agreements, but just generally, is this something you feel the need you try where protect ourselves against when you do go into an agreement? And in the future, if somebody launches something like this, do you expect more flexibility with being able to maybe tier those networks or drop them from the bundle? I mean how do you think about that dynamic in terms of protecting your own investment in the programming?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, our focus, first and foremost, is the customer. And we don't believe that our -- anywhere in our task is directing the customer one way or another that the -- So when CBS comes out with, I don't know, an over-the-top package, et cetera ri
componenttext: Well, first off, our focus, first and foremost, is the customer. And we don't believe that our -- anywhere in our task is directing the customer one way or another that the -- So when CBS comes out with, I don't know, an over-the-top package, et cetera right, that's more choice for our customer, right? They're still going to use our service to get it. And they so we're -- we really have that much difficulty on that, and there are plenty others who are doing over-the-top services too. But remember, if you heard earlier, I mean the video product itself is -- our biggest concern is that the customer have available to them a video product that they like at a price that they can afford. And so whether they get that through our big bundle or whether they get that through our cord-cutter package which allows them to get, for instance, CBS for free, to us, what's most important is that they're satisfied. And we focus on providing the best connectivity to them, so they can access all the bundles. [ph] So we don't see ourselves as trying to stop the flow of over-the-top programming to our customers. That isn't something that we are very interested in doing. And what was the other part of your question?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well maybe I'll ask the question more bluntly. Let's take something like ESPN, which is obviously an expensive programming cost for you.
componenttext: Well maybe I'll ask the question more bluntly. Let's take something like ESPN, which is obviously an expensive programming cost for you.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And they're talking about at some point going over-the-top. So if they launch an over-the-top service, would you still expect to pay full price for that in your most broadly distributed bundle? Or would you say if you're going to make that available direc
componenttext: And they're talking about at some point going over-the-top. So if they launch an over-the-top service, would you still expect to pay full price for that in your most broadly distributed bundle? Or would you say if you're going to make that available direct, perhaps we should at least be able to tier it out of our more basic package or give our customers more options?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we don't think like that. It's basically it's the same answer. Look, if ESPN does offer some over-the-top service, right, the -- and then one of our customers take the ESPN over-the-top service, right, then the likelihood is they're not a bundle subsc
componenttext: No, we don't think like that. It's basically it's the same answer. Look, if ESPN does offer some over-the-top service, right, the -- and then one of our customers take the ESPN over-the-top service, right, then the likelihood is they're not a bundle subscriber. The -- They're more likely -- they're, for sure, going to be a data subscriber because they're going to need the connectivity especially for that kind of programming. And they can very well have the digital antenna, et cetera. And they're still our customer and that's what we want. Now remember, it's on a per-customer basis that ESPN charges. So the -- if they're -- as long as their pricing -- they underprice us and go to the consumer with a lesser price than what they're getting from us -- which by the way, I can't imagine why they would do that the -- because they're just decreasing the overall revenue, right. The -- but if they did that, I could see us maybe going back to them and saying, "Hey look, we need to at least even up here." But other than that, I don't really -- we don't have a problem with it. Because it's not -- for us, it's not about the capturing the video customer. It's about connectivity. And we ultimately expect that customers will be getting a good portion of our customers will be getting their video product from over-the-top. It may take 5 to 10 years, but that is the way things are going to happen. And we think what we really like our customers to think is that the best way to get that, the best way to get that this with Cablevision with using our connectivity product.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Christie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Cablevision Systems Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call o
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Christie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Cablevision Systems Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Cindi Buckwalter, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Cablevision's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO; Kristin Dolan, Chief Operating Officer; and Brian Sweeney, President and Chief Financial Officer. Jim will start
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Cablevision's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Joining me this morning are Jim Dolan, CEO; Kristin Dolan, Chief Operating Officer; and Brian Sweeney, President and Chief Financial Officer. Jim will start off the call, and then Kristin will provide an operational and product update. Brian will conclude with a review of our financial results. Gregg Seibert, our Vice Chairman, will be available for Q&A. If you do not have a copy of today's earnings release, it is available on our website at cablevision.com.
Please note the following. Today's discussion may contain statements that constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance or results and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. Please refer to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of risks and uncertainties. The company disclaims any obligation to update the forward-looking statements that may be discussed during this call.
On Page 6 of today's earnings release, we provide a reconciliation of operating income to adjusted operating cash flow or AOCF.
I would now like to introduce Jim Dolan, CEO of Cablevision.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cindi, and good morning. Our second quarter financial results met our expectations. Consolidated revenue grew 2% and AOCF decreased 3% compared to the prior year period. Year-to-date, AOCF is in line with our 2015 outlook. Our capital expenditu
componenttext:
Thank you, Cindi, and good morning. Our second quarter financial results met our expectations. Consolidated revenue grew 2% and AOCF decreased 3% compared to the prior year period. Year-to-date, AOCF is in line with our 2015 outlook. Our capital expenditures during the quarter were $215 million. Free cash flow was $158 million. And we continued to return capital to shareholders with a dividend of $0.15 per share declared in August 6.  Overall, we're satisfied with our results.
Turning to operations. The metric we are most enthusiastic about is customer relationships. We gained 5,000 total customers, marking the first quarter of growth in more than 2 years. New technologies and consumer behaviors continue to challenge the big bundle. It's clear that this dynamic with the customer is changing, which is why today, the overall customer relationship number is more relevant than individual product metrics.
As a leading service provider in the most sophisticated markets in the country, we saw these trends coming. And that is why earlier this year, we were the first and only provider to introduce cord-cutter packages. We recognized that the traditional video bundle does not work for all consumers, so we are offering flexibility, choice and new products to meet their evolving connectivity needs.
We have been positioning the company to address this changing market for several years. Beginning in 2012, Cablevision embarked on a new strategic path to become the premier connectivity company in the New York market. We made substantial investments in technology, tools and people to provide the best experience to our customers. Most importantly, we focused on the reliability and performance of our network. As a result, we more than doubled our broadband capacity, optimized the density and quality of our WiFi experience, enabled the more innovative product set with flexible service offerings and improved our ability to monitor network performance and address issues proactively.
These investments have also made our operations more efficient. We have reduced trouble call truck rolls in half and customer calls by nearly 30% compared to the 2012 levels. This has led to lower costs and improved customer satisfaction. At the same time, we chose to complete -- compete on value, not solely on price by taking a more disciplined approach to promotional eligibility and customer credit policies. The changes to the way we do business has resulted in a stronger base of customers who are more satisfied. That has helped decreased our voluntary competitive churn to a nearly 6-year low in the second quarter.
On the product side, we've continue to innovate with our over-the-top offerings and recent speedy increase in our core data service. We've also changed the Cablevision employee experience by investing in the development of our people. As a result, we have created a performance-based culture throughout all levels of the company.
I'm going to close my portion of the call with some remarks about Verizon. Our first direct competition with them was in the landline phone business. From a standing start, we took more than 2 million of their residential phone customers, and Cablevision became the dominant phone provider in our market. Verizon has invested billions of dollars in FiOS in the tri-state area. Today, Cablevision serves more than 3.1 million customers, down from 3.3 million customers at our peak in 2008. This is despite FiOS' heavily bundled overbuild and deeply discounted pricing as well as the economy and other competitive forces. The impact of FiOS on Cablevision has been minimal. To the extent that we have lost customers to FiOS, we believe that they are usually promotional shoppers in search of the lowest price services. FiOS has almost certainly performed better against the satellite companies than it has against Cablevision. We believe that the Verizon FiOS is an unprofitable business today, and we doubt that they will ever be profitable.
Our strategic plan and investments during the past 3 years have helped to transform Cablevision. Our focus on price discipline has allowed us to grow revenue per customer. Our voluntary churn is down, and we have retained our highest-value customers. In addition today, Cablevision operates the nation's most robust WiFi network, while Verizon has no public WiFi. 
Cablevision has changed its culture. We no longer think like a monopoly, and instead, we are strategic, effective and competitive. Our approach to connectivity as a new frontier is gaining traction. This is reflected by our growth in customer relationships this quarter.
The Verizon FiOS effect, if there was ever -- if there ever was one, in our opinion, is over. Our business is healthy, and I'm confident that we'll get even stronger as we move forward.
With that, let me turn the call over to Kristin Dolan for an operational and product update.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. The actions we've taken over the last 3 years to reimagine Cablevision have resulted in a faster, more reliable network that excelled at delivering new and sophisticated products and services. Expanding on Jim's update, the improvements we
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. The actions we've taken over the last 3 years to reimagine Cablevision have resulted in a faster, more reliable network that excelled at delivering new and sophisticated products and services. Expanding on Jim's update, the improvements we have made have enhanced the customer experience and have reduced costly service-related transactions.  
For example, through proactive monitoring of the network, we're able to identify risk points and intervene before the customer is affected. We triage every trouble call before we roll a truck, identifying the source of the issue and eliminating unnecessary truck rolls. And we've armed our technicians with advanced tools that enable faster repair times and facilitate the goal of first call resolution, solving the problem in our first visit to the home. These initiatives are resonating with our customers and leading to a superior service experience. Accordingly, second quarter trouble call truck rolls decreased 19% as compared with the prior year period. We also experienced a 13% reduction in calls to customer service over the same period.
We implemented a voice of the customer dashboard earlier this year to capture real-time customer feedback and measure net promoter score, a tool widely used by many leading companies to obtain feedback from customers. Responses to this new approach have been strong. We'll harness the insights from these surveys to further improve customer satisfaction and operational efficiencies.
We've also continued to innovate in the product area. In the second quarter, we introduced our cord-cutter packages to serve a new generation that prefers to access video content through the Internet. The cord cutter offerings provide access to different levels of Internet service at varying price points. They all include a digital antenna at no charge for over-the-year TV. This allows customers to bypass the big bundle and still watch broadcast television as well as over-the-top content. These packages are attracting new interests. They have also allowed us to engage differently with consumers who are looking for options to fit their individual connectivity needs and budgets.
Changes in our acquisition and retention practices helped improve customer activities during the quarter, with fewer disconnects and an overall net gain of 5,000 total customers as Jim mentioned. We also experienced the largest quarterly data net additions since the first quarter of 2013.
Turning to our network. Our investments in this area have transformed our high-speed data service into the premier broadband offerings in the New York marketplace.  Let me share a few specifics. 
During the last 2 years, average daily usage per customer has increased by 190%. Today, 90% of customer relationships include broadband service. In addition, nearly half of Optimum Online customers currently subscribe to premium speed tiers, and more than half of data customers use 50 gigabits or more per month.
Now let's turn to WiFi. Over the last 3 years, WiFi access and usage has grown exponentially across all metrics. For example, Optimum WiFi access points have increased from less than 50,000 to more than 1.3 million. We rolled out 1 million in home smart routers at no incremental cost to our customers. And monthly WiFi data usage per customer increased from less than 1 gigabyte to more than 6 gigabytes over the same 3-year period. We will continue to make investments in our WiFi networks through the deployment of additional WiFi access points in high-data-usage areas.
Moving on. Other highlights for the quarter include offering HBO Now and Hulu as over-the-top alternatives to our broadband customers, entering into a long-term agreement with ESPN Disney for our data and analytics service, and continuing to work with other MSOs to provide combined insights for set-top box tuning data.
We're pleased with the progress in the first half of 2015, and we'll remain focused on delivering superior service and enhancing our customer relationships.
With that, let me turn to Brian Sweeney to review our financial results.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kristin, and good morning. During the quarter, total customers increased by 5,000 and high-speed data customers increased by 14,000. Video and voice customers declined by 16,000 and 7,000 respectively. We're seeing more favorable customer trend
componenttext:
Thank you, Kristin, and good morning. During the quarter, total customers increased by 5,000 and high-speed data customers increased by 14,000. Video and voice customers declined by 16,000 and 7,000 respectively. We're seeing more favorable customer trends over the last few quarters as a direct result of the numerous actions taken to increase broadband capacity, improve network reliability and enhance customer service. We have also built a stronger customer base with reduced churn and lower voluntary disconnects. Average monthly revenue per customer in the second quarter increased by nearly $6 to $158.52 as compared with the prior year period. This performance was principally driven by recent rate initiatives and our disciplined approach to promotional eligibility and retention policies, as well as increased transactional revenue from a pay-per-view event during the quarter.
Second quarter total cable revenue increased by 1.8%, reflecting the increase in revenue per customer, which was partially offset by fewer customers compared to the prior year period and lower advertising.
Cable AOCF decreased 3.4% in the second quarter as compared to the prior year period. This primarily reflects higher programming cost, legal fees, and product development and marketing costs, partially offset by the impact of revenue growth and lower customer service-related costs.
I want to provide a little more color on our advertising book. As compared with 2014, second quarter cable advertising revenue decreased by 11%, primarily due to reduced spending with fewer candidate campaigns this year, along with lower spending in the financial, gaming and cable programming sectors. The declines in certain categories of our advertising revenue were offset in part by higher local recreational and consumer spending. Notably, the number of addressable advertising campaigns doubled compared to the prior year period, and we are seeing pronounced interest in impression-based sales.
Moving on to CapEx. Cable capital spending in the second quarter was $186 million, a $21 million decrease from same period in 2014. This primarily reflects lower year-over-year spending on set-top box and modem purchases, as well as the timing of certain video-related projects. These declines were partially offset by higher project spending to support broadband and WiFi expansion. We expect increased CapEx spending in the back half of 2015 as we continue to invest in the evolution of our product offerings and ensure a quality service experience.
Moving on to our other business segments. Lightpath second quarter revenue increased 3% and AOCF grew nearly 12% as compared with the prior year period. The revenue increase reflects growth in Ethernet-based services, partially offset by the continuing decline in legacy TDM-based services. AOCF growth was also driven by lower expenses.
In our other segment, second quarter revenue decreased 3.7% and the AOCF deficit increased by 4%. The decrease in revenue was primarily due to lower advertising revenue at Newsday, partially offset by higher advertising revenue at News 12. The decline in AOCF reflects lower overall net revenues and higher employee-related cost to corporate, partially offset by a reduction in operating expenses at Newsday.
Now turning to the company's financial position. The company's second quarter consolidated cash position was $797 million, and net debt was $7.7 billion. We had $1.43 billion undrawn and available under the $1.5 billion revolving credit facility at CSC Holdings as of the end of the second quarter.  As previously mentioned on our May earnings call, during the second quarter, we made a voluntary repayment of our CSC Holdings term loan B facility in the amount of $200 million. This repayment will result in cash interest savings over the term of the facility. 
We remain focused on identifying opportunities to reduce leverage, strengthen our balance sheet and improve our liquidity position.  At June 30, the company's consolidated net leverage ratio was 4.1x. The CSC Holdings restricted group bank leverage ratio was 2.7x. 
We have not repurchased shares of Cablevision stock during 2015, and we have approximately $450 million of remaining stock repurchase authorization.
We continue to anticipate that 2015 total company AOCF and CapEx, including incremental expenditures for the product initiatives, will be substantially similar to our 2014 results.
Before we move to Q&A, we know the topic of M&A continues to be on all of your minds, but this call is to discuss our second quarter results. We will not be entertaining questions today relating to industry consolidation.
Operator, we would now like to open the call for questions.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Jessica Reif Cohen of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Jessica Reif Cohen of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess two questions. The first one, I just wanted -- I hope to follow up on what Kristin was just talking about on the video bundle. Can you -- Kristin, can you give any color on -- you guys offer more choice in different packages. This is obviously the
componenttext: I guess two questions. The first one, I just wanted -- I hope to follow up on what Kristin was just talking about on the video bundle. Can you -- Kristin, can you give any color on -- you guys offer more choice in different packages. This is obviously the -- I mean given what's happened in the last few days and the fear that the bundles are falling apart. In your experience, can you tell us, like, who's taking the nontraditional packages, the skinny packages? How quickly are you seeing customers to pick, go down and move down from the big video packages, traditional video packages to the skinny bundles?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me start with the skinny bundle. Let me talk about it differently, sorry. The cord-cutting packages are definitely making the phone ring, but the bulk of people are still buying 3 products. So -- and the cord-cutter packages are really going to new
componenttext: So let me start with the skinny bundle. Let me talk about it differently, sorry. The cord-cutting packages are definitely making the phone ring, but the bulk of people are still buying 3 products. So -- and the cord-cutter packages are really going to new acquisitions, the customers that we wouldn't normally get. So we're not seeing a migration of existing products moving to cord cutters or to skinnier bundles. We're really, I think, attracting new customers and also making the phone ring with the price point associated, and then upselling the bulk of those customers to a traditional 3-product bundle.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess just a follow-up, do you guys have a point of view on how quickly the traditional bundle will -- how much -- in terms of -- I'm sorry...
componenttext: So I guess just a follow-up, do you guys have a point of view on how quickly the traditional bundle will -- how much -- in terms of -- I'm sorry...

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. Hi Jessica. The -- I don't think the sky is falling quite yet. And I think that there's not enough programming weight yet in the Internet, right, and then in the over-the-top services that are out there to really entice a mainstream video custo
componenttext: Yes, I do. Hi Jessica. The -- I don't think the sky is falling quite yet. And I think that there's not enough programming weight yet in the Internet, right, and then in the over-the-top services that are out there to really entice a mainstream video customer. That the innovators, et cetera, some of the -- I don't call it fringe, but some of the -- not mainstream video watchers start to adopt the over-the-top. But the -- I do think eventually though that there will be enough of -- enough programming for over-the-top to be competitive with the traditional video bundle. The -- but this is not something that I think is going to happen over a very short period of time. The consumers have become very, very comfortable with the amount of choice that cable offers. And if you want to have a very, very wide variety of choice, that the bundle actually is somewhat still efficient, that the -- it's essentially buying the entire magazine stand even though you're going to -- because you want the choice of every magazine in there, but you only look at maybe several a day or whatever. But you don't want to give up your access to the whole magazine stand. The consumers have gotten very used to that, but it's pricey. And so the -- as you continue to see that price push up, which inevitably you will because the programmers are raising their rates on -- obviously, on a regular basis, particularly the broadcasters who see it as a bit of a pot of gold, that will drive the people who are more price-sensitive into alternatives. And Internet is obviously, IP over-the-top is starting to become a real alternative. And then with -- that is why we introduced the cord-cutter package with digital antenna. Because the digital antenna essentially takes the programming bundle up to the point where it is somewhat competitive with a traditional bundle and at a price that's affordable. So I think it's right for you to watch what happens with that, but I don't think that we're going to see a landslide of consumers move from one to the other. And my own prediction is that it will be at least 5 years for 10% of the market to move and 10 years for 30% of the market to move. How's that for an answer?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I just have one different question, which is, when would you reconsider reinstating the share repurchase program?
componenttext: Great. I just have one different question, which is, when would you reconsider reinstating the share repurchase program?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jessica, we view the dividend as the primary form of return of capital to our shareholders. The original repurchase programs were put in place at a time when we had transactions that, for one reason or another, provided additional liquidity, such as the s
componenttext: Jessica, we view the dividend as the primary form of return of capital to our shareholders. The original repurchase programs were put in place at a time when we had transactions that, for one reason or another, provided additional liquidity, such as the spin-off of AMC, which provided a lot of liquidity for share repurchase. But I think now the board is quite comfortable with the dividend being the primary return of capital. I'm not going to rule it out, but we'd look at it only on an opportunistic basis at this point in time. We've been reinvesting in the business, Paying the dividend, those are -- and deleveraging. Those are the primary uses of capital.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ben Swinburne of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have one for Jim and then just a quick one for Brian. Jim, on -- you repositioned the company as a connectivity company as you said, and the subscriber numbers are showing that's been quite successful. Interestingly, Verizon seems to be going a little b
componenttext: I have one for Jim and then just a quick one for Brian. Jim, on -- you repositioned the company as a connectivity company as you said, and the subscriber numbers are showing that's been quite successful. Interestingly, Verizon seems to be going a little bit in the opposite direction with their Go90 product, where they're actually going into the programming business. So when you guys look at your product suite and all of the innovation you've got there, which again seems to be resonating nicely, do you ever think about getting into mobile programming package business? Or do you think that's just the wrong strategy? And then Brian, I'm just wondering if you could talk about the pay-per-view impact in the quarter for us, given that was an unusually unpopular fight, so we can understand that.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm actually going to pass that one over to Kristin because that's really her -- that's her sweet spot area. So go ahead now.
componenttext: I'm actually going to pass that one over to Kristin because that's really her -- that's her sweet spot area. So go ahead now.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I know -- I didn't know Brian was going to to go first. But yes, we've had programming in the past that we've spun. We understand the business really well. I think it's a crowded marketplace right now where I think they have seen successes, things li
componenttext: Yes, I know -- I didn't know Brian was going to to go first. But yes, we've had programming in the past that we've spun. We understand the business really well. I think it's a crowded marketplace right now where I think they have seen successes, things like having Major League Baseball available on an exclusive basis to mobile customers. It's a really expensive proposition. I don't think necessarily that it's additive to our overall strategy. I don't think it generates incremental revenue particularly. And our focus is really on delivering the product, having the best service and the best pipeline to deliver whatever anybody wants to buy from us or from over-the-top providers. So I don't see the mobile content strategy as being one that would really be critical to our overall approach.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that the mobile carriers are trying to differentiate themselves. That they -- because they don't have much to differentiate themselves. So I mean, that's why I think -- that's why they're -- the best thing in that kind of thing, but I think it's r
componenttext: I think that the mobile carriers are trying to differentiate themselves. That they -- because they don't have much to differentiate themselves. So I mean, that's why I think -- that's why they're -- the best thing in that kind of thing, but I think it's really all about mobile revenue, right? It's not about a new product set, it's about winning the battle against the competitor for them.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the pay-per-view question, that fight was actually the most successful pay-per-view event that we ever had, so it did have a meaningful contribution on revenue. I think on a AOCF basis, it contributed about $5 million of AOCF during the quarter. We're
componenttext: On the pay-per-view question, that fight was actually the most successful pay-per-view event that we ever had, so it did have a meaningful contribution on revenue. I think on a AOCF basis, it contributed about $5 million of AOCF during the quarter. We're also quite pleased with all the enhancements that we've put in the network that we didn't have any customer service issues in dealing with the huge interest that was in that fight.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from Marci Ryvicker of Wells Fargo.

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have two. Jim, when you talked about Verizon at the beginning, you often get asked in these calls if there's any change in competition, and normally, the answer is no. So when you come out with such strong commentary, is it that competition is actually
componenttext: I have two. Jim, when you talked about Verizon at the beginning, you often get asked in these calls if there's any change in competition, and normally, the answer is no. So when you come out with such strong commentary, is it that competition is actually getting easier? I mean, FiOS [indiscernible] the best numbers? Or is Cablevision just that much stronger? That's the first question. And then the second question, do you envision as video subs go down, whatever it is, 10% or 30%, that you can make all of that up in high-speed data pricing in tiers? Or is it your vision that at some point, you're in a -- or the industry's in a secular decline?

headline: Cablevision Systems Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. The first one was about -- I'm getting old, I'm sorry. What was the first question about?
componenttext: Okay. The first one was about -- I'm getting old, I'm sorry. What was the first question about?
